<xhtml:span id="h4" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... exactly right, they get to sit at the table with the <xhtml:span class="hit">regulators</xhtml:span> which means they'll benefit and find a way to maneuver any  <xhtml:span class="hit">regulations</xhtml:span> coming down the pipe. BARTIROMO: Diamond & Silk are testifying this ...</xhtml:span>

<xhtml:span id="h5" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... sign for business ahead. HEGSETH: How often do you hear about <xhtml:span class="hit">regulation</xhtml:span> or the reduction thereof and how significant that's been? MILLER: It ...</xhtml:span>

<xhtml:span id="h6" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... run your business, on top of that, how to understand the <xhtml:span class="hit">regulations</xhtml:span>,  it's a lot for one person to take....</xhtml:span>

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S6J-F391-DY0W-44D8-00000-00Facebook's 1Q Beat; Comey Struggle to Defend Leaks; Celebrities Opening Up About Mental Illness; Small Business in America; Tax Reform Windfall; Ford To Drop Most Sedans; NYC Judge Rules Trump Supporters Can Be Refused Service; Adidas Launches Dad Shoe; Lebron's Buzzer Beater; OKC Erases 25-Point Deficit; 2018 NFL Draft2018-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:38ZLexisNexisFacebook's 1Q Beat; Comey Struggle to Defend Leaks; Celebrities Opening Up About Mental Illness; Small Business in America; Tax Reform Windfall; Ford To Drop Most Sedans; NYC Judge Rules Trump Supporters Can Be Refused Service; Adidas Launches Dad Shoe; Lebron's Buzzer Beater; OKC Erases 25-Point Deficit; 2018 NFL DraftLanhamFULL TEXT

. MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Here there ladies, good morning to you. Thanks so much Gerri. Good morning, everybody, thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, April 26thm happy Thursday. Your top stories right now 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

It is the busiest single day of earnings season so far, industry giants like General Motors, Starbucks, Amazon, Microsoft all reporting their quarterly results today. Ahead of the earning splits, Futures indicating higher opening for the broader averages. Check it out, Dow Industrials up about 30 points right now, it's a fractional move on a percentage basis. So as is the S&P500, the NASDAQ right now, up half a percent, 33 points higher.

The Dow snapped a five-day losing streak yesterday lifted by Boeing's big earnings beat. Stock was strong. In yesterday's closing session, the Dow ended up 60 points, the S&P was up five, and the NASDAQ was down a fraction, three and a half points lower.

In Europe this morning, we've got gains across the board. Fractional move but the FT-100 is up 12, CAC Quarante in Paris is up 24 and the DAX Index up 21 points.

Investors are waiting on the European Central Bank decision this morning, that's due out in the next hour. No change in rates expected but the focus will be on the ECB President, Mario Draghi and his comments about the Future stimulus during his news conference. We'll bring you all the news from Europe coming up.

In Asia Overnight markets were mixed, the Shanghai Composite down one and a third percent, worst performer in China as you see.

And Facebook back on Wall Street's friends list, the stock soaring in the premarket this morning due to strong first quarter results showing an increase in daily users and monthly users despite the ongoing data scandal. The stock at 107 and change right now, we're breaking down those numbers, talk with Dan Niles, his number one position there coming up.

Another speed bump for Tesla to report, the new trouble for Elon Musk's electric automaker as the key member of the autopilot team departs amid new safety questions.

Then from flamethrowers to fire breathers, Elon Musk reveals his latest project, a cyborg dragon. The first details on the wild new robot coming up this morning.

And then walk a mile in dad shoes, Adidas unveils the perfect sneaker for keeping that dad bod in top shape.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to talk all about it, FOX Business Network's Dagen McDowell. The Wall Street Journal's Assistant Editorial Page Editor, James Freeman along with Iraq and Afghanistan War Veteran, FOX News Contributor, Pete Hegseth is here. Great to see you Pete.

PETE HEGSETH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Great to see -- if those are the world's best sneakers, the world has gone mad.

BARTIROMO: Really?

HEGSETH: They're OK but the best? I don't know.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: The trend in cool sneakers is the uglier and the more expensive.

HEGSETH: Oh, really.

MCDOWELL: I can find you a pair of $1,200 sneakers that certainly none of your children would be caught wearing it.

BARTIROMO: But can you press a button and order pizza from it?

MCDOWELL: No. Actually, you know what --

HEGSETH: That's true. That's true.

BARTIROMO: We have no sneakers (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: Those shoes -- those -- I'm talking about sneakers so expensive, they should come with their own brick pizza oven quite frankly.

BARTIROMO: A lot going on this morning, biggest day in earnings so far.

FREEMAN: Yes, I think it's exciting to have the dad bod trend continue but, yes, you -- expectation is so high for American business and American business keeps beating them. So we'll see again today if the Facebook pattern continues to the rest of the techs.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We're talking about 18, 19 percent earnings growth for the S&P500 for the first quarter, same thing for 2018.

MCDOWELL: But with valuations going into this quarter, it has to be better than perfect. There is no such thing as 110 percent in terms of you can deliver a 100 percent but they need to deliver more than that.

One of the things that Facebook did yesterday and we'll get into it is they up the buybacks. So they're going to buyback an additional $9 billion in shares adding to the $6 billion previously authorized. So I think Facebook management stepped back and said, "We need to do something to reduce this stock."

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, we'll see about that. It is getting juiced this morning, that's for sure.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: It's up pretty big. Coming up this morning, joining the conversation, the Chairman of the House Republican Conference and Washington Congresswoman, Cathy McMorris Rodgers is with us. California Congressman, John Garamendi is here along with Alpha One Capital Partners Founding Partner, Dan Niles who predicted a very good quarter for Facebook by the way, he's going to weigh in on the numbers. Plus, Universal Health Services Founder and CEO, Alan Miller is with us as well. Don't miss a moment of it.

We kick it off right here this hour with this, the technology earnings blitz on Wall Street, investors are watching Amazon, Microsoft, and Intel all ahead of their results after the bell tonight and it's going to be important given what's been going on with tech.

Meanwhile, Facebook topped Wall Street expectations yesterday reporting adjusted earnings of $1.69 a share, revenue coming in $11.97 billion. It is the technology titan's first earnings report since the user data crisis, the stock is trading up this morning. As you can see, up six and two- thirds percent or $10-1/2 a share, James Freeman, your reaction to the Facebook news.

FREEMAN: Yes. I think it's probably sometimes difficult for people to understand why a company can have all of these bad headlines and have its business performing so well. And I think it's a couple of things.

One is that while people are concerned about their data, they obviously value what they get from Facebook in terms of the ability to communicate with friends more than they're concerned about having to share information about themselves. The other issue is that even if regulation comes, big incumbent in an industry tend to do fine. We have a heavy regulated situation, the barriers to entry, the smaller competitors go up, and the new side of our paper had a story this week about an E.U. regulator going out to California talking to the big tech companies about privacy regulations.

She thought they were going to freak out and they said, "No, we're good." This regulation is always a bigger burden for the smaller competitors. So if it comes in the U.S., you worry about the next challenger to Facebook more than Facebook.

BARTIROMO: That's interesting because even the company's total cost in expenses were up 39 percent year-over-year in the first quarter but the acceleration of expense growth is driven by other things, the anticipation of regulation driven by security, content investment, and long-term bets like IA.

FREEMAN: Yes. Now they did say to expect higher expenses going forward and some of that will be I'm sure having to deal with compliance and political nuttiness side of Washington but the business is very healthy because people despite their unease welcome the trade. I give you my data, you know all about me and then return, I get lots of services for free.

BARTIROMO: Especially young people. Especially young people.

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So far, people think that way.

FREEMAN: So far. That's right.

MCDOWELL: And he added 70 million monthly, uses a lot of what was discovered about -- and by the way, people keep referring to this as the Cambridge Analytica scandal at Facebook --

BARTIROMO: I know, it's ridiculous.

MCDOWELL: This is a scan -- this is a gross misuse and reckless disregard for people's privacy in data literally for more than the last decade.

BARTIROMO: No. Let's go back to the Barrack Obama years and what -- he was a master at mining all of the data. And Facebook was like, "Come on in, here's all of our user information."

MCDOWELL: Let's go back --

HEGSETH: And (INAUDIBLE) Facebook into the head of the curve.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: Well the -- it started even before that. It started even before President Obama won the White House the first go around. It started back in 2007. The bigger -- so the question is --

BARTIROMO: But it was really effective for the Obama presidency.

MCDOWELL: In 2012 for sure. So will Facebook user stick around? Will the user growth continue to go great guns the way it has? And tell you, what are the advertisers going to do?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And so far based on just anecdotal information and evidence that the Wall Street Journal collected, Sheryl Sandberg said yesterday the company hasn't seen a meaningful trend of advertisers leaving the platform but it's still a wait and see. Plus, the stock through yesterday's close was down 18 percent from the record high in early February.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So you get a boost this morning, it's still off nearly 20 percent.

BARTIROMO: Well the advertisers aren't stupid, they want the 2.2 billion users on them.

HEGSETH: Of course. And the 2.2 billion users are -- they may have been a Few bad headlines but if you were logging on to Facebook yesterday, you're logging on to Facebook today, they have been incredibly effective at monetizing their business model.

And as James says, he's exactly right, they get to sit at the table with the regulators which means they'll benefit and find a way to maneuver any regulations coming down the pipe.

BARTIROMO: Diamond & Silk are testifying this morning before the House Judiciary Committee after saying that their conservative content on Facebook was censored. The Congressional panel also inviting representatives from Facebook, Google, and Twitter to the hearing on social media filtering practices and its effect on free speech.

Bottom line here, this is one of the issues that Congress is most upset about and that they're going to be pressing --

HEGSETH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- the fact that they are deciding what we see and what we hear.

HEGSETH: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: And that's what Diamond & Silk are going to be testifying about today.

HEGSETH: It will be great TV I'll tell you that.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HEGSETH: I mean, they don't hold back, set your DVRs, I'm sure it will be fascinating. But they -- their finger is on the pulse of what I think is the biggest concern for many Americans around Facebook, is my content being blocked based on algorithm I'm not aware of?

BARTIROMO: That's right.

HEGSETH: And is there an ideological slant to that algorithm and people -- they have a platform to speak out. Most people who are speaking out don't and have this sense that their content isn't reaching people, a big concern for --

BARTIROMO: That's why they don't get sued because they're supposed to be the area that people from all different areas can talk and exchange ideas.

HEGSETH: But they're not.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But they're -- they may not be, that's the issue.

MCDOWELL: But if you're pro-life and pro second amendment, your content will be taken down quite frankly in some instances. I've had friends --

HEGSETH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: That's wrong.

MCDOWELL: I've had friends that experience that. There was an incident that I believe Mark Zuckerberg was asked about when he testified in front of Congress, it was a Catholic University's content of Jesus on the cross was censored.

HEGSETH: Yes. Yes.

MCDOWELL: And he did -- and he acted like -- he played dumb. Maybe he didn't know about that one instant. But, again, they're trying to be more transparent Facebook is.

BARTIROMO: Are they trying? That's what I wanted to see, actually the effort because I don't know about that.

MCDOWELL: They're trying to be -- they're trying to be more (INAUDIBLE) until the users, what would trigger con -- basically content censorship.

FREEMAN: Yes. I think this is going to be an increasing issue. I mean, you celebrate these social media companies because they did disrupt media in the sense that the New York Times doesn't have the political, cultural power it used to given that everyone can communicate now. But this is the question, are they the new gatekeepers that are going to do what the yield gatekeepers did in screening out opinions that don't agree with.

BARTIROMO: Are you a platform or are you a gatekeeper? We got to talk about former FBI Director Jim Comey, did anybody see that interview last night? I tweeted this, "Wow, just wow."

His leaked memos, a catalyst for the special counsel investigation was more widely shared than previously thought. Source is telling FOX News that Comey likely gave his documents to former U.S. Attorney Patrick Fitzgerald and possibly another person, along with the Columbia law school professor. Watch this as Comey tries to defend his actions of leaking the memos to the professor last night in the CNN Town Hall, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do you think that there's any credence from the president's claims that you broke the law when you released your memos?

JAMES COMEY, FORMER FBI DIRECTOR: I don't. That won't surprise you, I don't. In fact, I think he's just making stuff up. I didn't leak memos, I asked a friend to communicate the substance of one unclassified --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: (INAUDIBLE)

COMEY: I intentionally gave this information to a friend intending that it would be out in the media, I wanted it to get in the media.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Right.

COMEY: As a private citizen, I could do that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Just because you say you're not leaking, Dagen, doesn't mean you're not leaking. We're not idiots, OK? We're not morons. You actually leaked a memo to your friend who's a professor, now you're saying, "I didn't leak it because I told him, "Oh, get it to the New York Times, just the content, don't give the actual paper." I mean, this is -- I'm outraged.

MCDOWELL: You just defined what the word leak means.

BARTIROMO: Does he think anyone is buying this?

MCDOWELL: He doesn't care if they're buy -- he only cares if they're buying that book that he's written. I tweeted last night, I said, "To call Washington, D.C. a bunch -- a snake pit is an insult to snakes."

FREEMAN: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: He -- the -- what did he say, "That I'm not a weasel" that was in the notes that were --

BARTIROMO: Oh, he came off like such a weasel last night.

MCDOWELL: I don't know if he told the president I'm not a weasel. Again, by his actions, defining what weasel means.

BARTIROMO: Isn't that extraordinary though that --

MCDOWELL: He's not funny actually. I'm laughing --

BARTIROMO: It's really not funny because he's taking advantage of this platform that he has with this book tour and just ignoring facts.

HEGSETH: Let him keep speaking. Please, keep speaking. Let us see more documents, let the investigations continue because all it does is exonerate the collusion and all of the narratives they have and expose the snake pit for what it is.

He says, "I'm a private citizen" yet the day before you weren't and the document you created isn't private and you have no right to leak it and the fact that he did what he did, he's a leaking launderer, right? He wanted to launder his leaks through somebody else that he could write his (INAUDIBLE) it's all absurd.

BARTIROMO: It's incredible.

FREEMAN: Well --

MCDOWELL: I just want to point out, the Wall Street Journal has been writing about what a weasel this guy is --

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- literally since before 2003.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: They warned President Obama not to appoint him as the FBI Director, the y-- the editorial page at the Journal warned President Trump, nothing (INAUDIBLE)

HEGSETH: James, how did you know?

MCDOWELL: Because if you go through the man's history, he abuses power, there's prosecutorial overreach, he is not a boy scout, he is less than a snake.

BARTIROMO: Right. Right.

FREEMAN: Thank you. Now, that's the pattern overtime and you saw it with the e-mail investigation, you saw it with him basically running a rough shot over longstanding Justice Department policies, acting as if he's a prosecutor, he's not -- his job, head of the FBI to investigate and a lot of prosecutors to make the appropriate decisions.

So it's just over and over again not following the rules but it's funny, when you play that clip, I haven't seen it before and he started describing what he was doing --

BARTIROMO: Right.

FREEMAN: -- thought, "Gee, that sounds a lot like leaking." What am I missing here?

BARTIROMO: Exactly. But kudos to Anderson Cooper and he did the stick to the fire on that question and say, "But isn't that leaking over and over again?" To me, that was such arrogance and then to go on all of these shows and say the president is unfit to be president.

You're unfit to be FBI director. I mean, that's what's really clear. But the arrogance is up there with -- remember Shkreli when he was playing videogames in the courtroom, that's where this arrogance is, I equate the same.

FREEMAN: And confidence, I don't want to change the subject too much. But you look at the resources, is FBI devoted to enforcing the rules of college basketball? Meanwhile ignoring for example this horrendous scandal in gymnastics that was going on at the same time. I mean, there's a long list of not just the ethical issues but the confidence issues when he was running the FBI.

BARTIROMO: Sure is. All right, thank you for that. We're going to take a break. When we come back, a manhunt is underway this morning for a suspect accused of killing a main police officer then stealing his police cruiser. The latest on the search, plus a startling new statistic about how many of our heroes have been killed already this year.

Plus, Tesla's rough ride ahead of the self-driving business quits amidst continuing safety issues. Meanwhile, Elon Musk announces a shocking new robot venture, we've got all the details right here. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A cop killer is on the loose in Maine this morning. An urgent manhunt underway, Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN ANCHOR: That's right Maria. Police are on the lookout for this man, this is John Williams. They say the 29-year-old gun down Deputy Eugene Cole yesterday morning in Norridgewock, Maine, that is just north of Augusta.

Williams then drove the cruiser to a nearby convenient store and robbed it. Police releasing this photo captured of him from inside of that stolen car. He then abandoned the car nearby, he has not been seen since. Deputy Cole had been on the force for 13 years, he lives behind a son.

The attack coming just a day after two officers were shot in a Dallas Home Depot, one of those officers was killed. Official Rogelio Santander died from his injuries after police say Armando Juarez shot him in the back of the head while trying to make an arrest. Twenty-two officers have been shot and killed so far this year, that is more than double from the same time last year. On average, at least one officer reportedly has been shot to death every week so far in 2018.

Well, Tesla suffering a major lost in its self-driving car program. The leader of that division has left the company. Jim Keller has taken a job at Intel making him the latest to the string of very high level departures from Tesla. The self-driving program under new scrutiny after a Model X driver died using autopilot in a crash south of San Francisco last month.

Meanwhile, Elon Musk is already on to his next project, he casually tweeted last night that he's building a cyborg dragon. Yes, you heard me correctly. He didn't give us any more details, it's unclear what he plans to do with the sci-fi robot but, yes, the cyborg dragon. Shares of Tesla Maria are lower in the premarket but he's going to build a cyborg dragon. Well, I'll let you sponge on that one.

BARTIROMO: What is that? What's a cyborg dragon?

CASONE: We don't know, that's all he tweets.

BARTIROMO: It's just a robot.

CASONE: Oki-dokie, we'll look for that. Fix your cars.

BARTIROMO: OK. Robots, take it over man.

MCDOWELL: I just have to share this tweet from one of the viewers, Michael Hutchins related to the Comey discussion. Remember what George Costanza told Jerry Seinfeld, "It's not a lie if you believe it."

BARTIROMO: Right. Right.

MCDOWELL: So, again, it's turned into a Seinfeld episode. I wanted to pass that along.

BARTIROMO: Well we'll see what the I.G. report says about Jim Comey and the Hillary Clinton e-mail investigation because that's going to be the focus in the next I.G. report that's coming out in the month of May. We know what the earlier I.G. report, it recommended criminal charges against Andrew McCabe.

HEGSETH: Yes, absolutely. And we were talking in between, the vast difference between how James Comey has treated others and the treatment he expects themselves, it is offensive on how he looks down to people in a condescending way.

BARTIROMO: It really is. We'll take a break. When we come back, good news for the president, a new poll shows that Americans believe President Trump's policies are helping the economy. We're taking a closer look at those policies and how they're giving small businesses a big boost.

Then George H.W. Boost is out of intensive care and his biggest concern, the health of his beloved Houston Rockets, more on that coming up this morning, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Earnings alert, Universal Health Services reporting after the bell last night. Profit and revenue up from a year ago. The company is shy of analyst expectations. However, the numbers Universal reporting adjusted earnings of $2.45 a share on revenue of $2.69 billion.

Joining me right now is the Founder and CEO of Universal Health Services, Alan Miller. Alan, great to see you.

ALAN MILLER, FOUNDER & CEO, UNIVERSAL HEALTH SERVICES: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us. Characterize the quarter for us, what went off?

MILLER: Well, we have two big segments. One segment outpace the industry, the other segment is catching up. We've had some issues of shortage of doctors and nurses and a few other incidents, and we're in the U.K. which is going really well.

BARTIROMO: The hospital segment in general has been struggling because we see that the needs will get bigger and consolidate within hospitals. Do you still see that?

MILLER: Yes. There's consolidation because the insurance companies don't want to pay and they're finding all kinds of ways to deny payment even after we provide the service.

So -- I mean, that's not a good basis for business. So we're letting them know about it, we're suing them if we have to. But the demand is so great that the business is just a very sound business. And we are -- and have been from the outset a pioneer in mental health and mental health now as you well know, two things are happening, people are recognizing that we have mental health problems, 20 percent of the people in the country will have a problem over their lifetime. So, multiple it out, it's about 60 million people and we understand that half of those people don't get treatment.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

MILLER: So, we see results of a lot of it, in the news unfortunately, they have to treated. And the other thing that's happening which is good is that people have gotten over the stigma of having a mental health person in the family--

BARTIROMO: Celebrities are coming forward about their illnesses, that sort of --

MILLER: Yes, the rock just came out --

BARTIROMO: --taken some of the stigma away.

MILLER: Exactly. And we work with Herschel Walker, bless him who -- Herschel was a great, great football player and a rock of a man, like the other Rock who just came out and Herschel like problems. These are in people's heads, not in their physical body and you -- and the thing that we picked up on early was you can't be well, you -- if you're only well medically unless you're well upstairs --

BARTIROMO: Of course.

MILLER: And people have not realized that.

BARTIROMO: Yes. What can we do about it now? I mean, even five-time Grammy Winner Mariah Carey recently disclosing in People Magazine she suffers from bipolar disorder. Other singers and athletes also coming up like Demi Lovato, Johnny Mandel --

MILLER: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: -- you mentioned Kevin Love. What's the progress? What can we do about it? Are they promising drugs out there?

MILLER: It's not really the drugs, they have to -- if they're treated, if they're seen earlier, then things can happen, psychologists, it's not only drugs. By the time you get to the drugs, perhaps they're in a -- they're in a second stage.

BARTIROMO: Well that's right. And the drugs can be really harmful by the way. Look at opioids, right, a recent study by the Institute for Human for Human Data Science finds that opioid prescriptions actually fell last year by 10 percent --

MILLER: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- but the National Institute on Drug abuse found that 150 people a day are dying from opioid overdoes.

MILLER: Yes. But now there's pressure on doctors, that's the easy way. People have pain, they give them opioid which does a short-term drug on the pain but then they'll become addicted, so we can't do that.

So they're cutting back on that and they're using ibuprofen and Aleve and this and that and they're finding out that it's helpful, more so than they thought.

BARTIROMO: So where does the grow come from at Universal, let's call it the next years?

MILLER: Right. Well number one, people are aging and we are building, build a--we build hospital a year in acute care. And they've been spectacular. We build in Southern California, we build in Henderson, in Las Vegas. There's tremendous demand.

We also build in our psych division behavioral health and there's great need for that and we're overseas in the U.K. So we have three legs which I always wanted --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MILLER: -- and all of them are growing. And we have been at is as talked, this will be our 40th year.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations Al.

MILLER: Thank you. So people rely on us, they know that we do the right thing and I know that we're concerned about the patients.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because- -

MILLER: Patients first is our concern.

BARTIROMO: We're living longer and with that, we're leading more in our older years for sure.

MILLER: But I'm very happy about the fact that these -- you mentioned Mandel, Dwayne, "The Rock," we've had Herschel for years, are making it understood in society now that this is just like a sickness.

If someone has a gallbladder problem, nobody thinks twice about getting it treated. "Oh, my son had a gallbladder or broke his arm or whatever," mental health should be in that category.

BARTIROMO: Well it's taking a while because I don't know that we've actually had the treatments out there for mental health as prevalent as treatment trough other things. So for example, autism, Alzheimer's, I mean we're studying the brain right now more and more, to learn more about these things.

But we know a lot more about diabetes, we know a lot more about cancer. I mean, that's the point.

MILLER: Yes. But the ones you mentioned are the generative, et cetera. I'm talking about younger people who are fighting bipolar, It's a complicated society, there's a lot of pressures and a lot of people have all of these pressures and they turn into depression and anxiety.

And the thing that really troubles me because we're very involved with the military and think a great deal of them.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MILLER: They used to be two great institutions, one of them is the military and the other was the FBI. And so --

BARTIROMO: Isn't that a shame? Isn't that a shame?

MILLER: It is a shame.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MILLER: It's a -- it is a shame.

BARTIROMO: Alan, thank you for coming in this morning.

MILLER: You're very welcome. Great to see you again.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you. Alan Miller joining us there, Universal Health Services.

Coming up, Ford cars are dead, long live the SUV. The auto maker is making big changes that looked to drive the company into the future.

Plus, drive-through Chipotle after posting better than expected earnings. The CEO is outlying changes as the band looks for a new direction there, we've got it all after this break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo, happy Thursday, it is Thursday, April 26th, your top stories right now 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast. The busiest day for earnings yet, among the top names reporting their first quarter this morning, Amazon, Microsoft, Intel, those are coming out after the bell, tonight. And Southwest Airlines just reported mixed results this morning.

Ford, meanwhile, making major line-up changes, get this, the automaker will only sell two cars at dealerships as drivers favor trucks and SUVs, find out which cars are staying on the lot. Chipotle, in earnings winner, the struggling restaurant chain is showing signs of a turn around, the company's profit and same store sales, beating expectations.

Broader markets, this morning, looking good, we are expecting a higher opening for the broader averages, Dow industrials set to open up about 30 points, S&P is up three points and the NASDAQ right now, up a half a percent, that's 32 points higher.

The Dow, meanwhile, snapped a five-day losing streak yesterday, lifted by a big beat from Boeing, Boeing stocks was strong as a Dow component, it lifted the Dow up about 60 points, a quarter percent higher. The NASDAQ was lower yesterday by a fraction. In Europe this morning, we are looking at money moving into stocks, FT 100, CAC Quarante and the DAX Index are higher, even if just by a fraction.

We are waiting on the European Central Bank decision this morning, that is due out in the next hour, we will have the news for you as soon as it hits the tape. No change on rates expected, but we will be watching the ECB President, Mario Draghi, comment and his news conference about what he says about stimulus going forward.

In Asia overnight, markets were mixed. The Shanghai Composite, worst performer, down one and a third percent. Targeting Trump supporters, a New York City bar allowed to throw out patrons wearing Make America Great Again hats, the outrage, coming up this morning. And then from ugly to cool, Adidas unveiling a dead shoe, how much it costs, coming up.

All those stories coming up this morning, but first, this, another sign of economic optimism, according to a new poll from Fox News, 43 percent of Americans are happy with the economy, with nine percent calling it excellent. A Fox Business exclusive now, a new study from Bank of America shows growing optimism among small business owners in America, 54 percent of small business owners expect to see economic strengthening in the coming year. Joining us right now to talk more about that is Bank of America Head of Small Business, Sharon Miller, Sharon, good to see you.

SHARON MILLER, HEAD, SMALL BUSINESS, BANK OF AMERICA: Great to see you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What were the reasons that they were so optimistic? Tell us about this new outlook.

MILLER: Well, tax reform was certainly a game-changer, we heard loud and clear from our small business owners that they were very optimistic following the tax reform and that's more money to invest back into their business, whether it's hiring more people, buying more equipment, whatever it may be, but it is definitely a game-changer.

BARTIROMO: And you wonder how long the runway this has, given the fact that we've already seen a real impact from the tax cut plan, but it's expected to keep having an impact over the year.

JAMES FREEMAN, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: Yes, I think the stock prices obviously get revised immediately, but as far as small business, what is the outlook in terms of how it changes this coming year?

MILLER: Well, small business, it's a local business and so what we are seeing across the United States is optimism. The headline is that we've seen more optimistic, people are very positive about the outlook in their local economies as well as the national economy, and that's a good sign for business ahead.

HEGSETH: How often do you hear about regulation or the reduction thereof and how significant that's been?

MILLER: It is, I mean, it is significant. The less bureaucracy you have, the less red tapes, so to speak. It's better for business and they are able to be more efficient, they're able to get through and understand what the impacts are on their business. So this is a positive for small business owners, it can be very complex and then trying to understand how to run your business, on top of that, how to understand the regulations, it's a lot for one person to take.

MCDOWELL: How does this optimism, though, translate into ramping up economic growth in this country whether it's through hiring, raises or investment in their businesses?

MILLER: Well, we are seeing all of that. The one thing that I would point to, is there is a war for talent out there. Small business owners, I talk to them all the time, across the country, they want to hire, they want to attract good employees, and the right employees that are quality and that understand their business and can add value to them.

And what's happening is it's just -- because of such a great economy and the very low unemployment, we are not able to find qualified workers in the small business camps. And so you've got to look at benefits, you've got to look at all sights -- sorts of other things to attract the right workers into the small businesses.

FREEMAN: So, Sharon, we are seeing this surge in confidence and optimism among the business owners, but generally, we haven't seen, over the last year, a lot of loan growth or maybe not as much as we'd like to see, do you see that changing now or are there reasons why we shouldn't be concerned even if the loan growth isn't off the charts?

MILLER: Well, I think there's -- you know, there's different segments with loan growth. And so in the small business face Bank of America, we are seeing demand for lending. Our lending is strong and I would say that, you know, when small businesses get started, generally, they will start with either personal savings, perhaps a credit card, and then they are able to get more traditional financing.

We also partner with community development financial institutions for these small businesses that may not be eligible for traditional financing. But we are seeing demand both in our traditional lines and loans as well as our health care, so lending to dentists, doctors, veterinarians.

HEGSETH: Sharon, but not all small businesses are created equal, some sectors are struggling, may not feel optimism, where do you see the most optimism and what places are not?

MILLER: Well, I think, in the technology section, and certainly, there was a question in our survey that was all around, what do you think about digital payments? And half of our small business owners felt like over the next five years, that's all they would be taking.

So instead of checks and instead of the way we may pay traditionally today, especially to small business in the local (INAUDIBLE) landscaper, you know your dry cleaner. They are talking about all digital payments which is, you know, quite -- there's a trickle down there because there's people that have to build those types of capabilities.

BARTIROMO: So, you've got nearly one-third of all small businesses using smart phones --

MILLER: Yes.

BARTIROMO: to process digital payments, that's interesting. Are the small businesses having their access to credit? I mean, how is that going in terms of business getting the credit that they need? That was one issue that Linda McMahon brought up when she joined us, the Small Business Administrator, earlier in the week.

MILLER: Yes. And there is access to capital, I mean, that's something that we want to make sure they were out there, we're teaching people how to get access to capital and what you need to do when you're starting a small business, how you have to have revenues that are going to be able to repay that loan, so access to capital can come in more ways than just a traditional loan and there's education, there's training.

We are very focused on women, we just announced, last week, the Institute for Women's Entrepreneurship and Bank of America partnership with Cornell University, this is all about our attempt to make sure that we're giving the education, the training and the information necessary for people to get access to capital. Many people don't know how to do it.

BARTIROMO: So, compare women start-ups to male start-ups, what's higher?

MILLER: Women are starting businesses at twice the rate of men with half the capital. And so, it say, it's definitely a great opportunity for us to partner. We will be, in fact, at Times Square, this week. We are posting poster love for Small Business. We want to make sure that, you know, if you like a small business, go online, give a good review for them because that's going to help them in the local economy. So there's a lot of opportunity for us to support small businesses and it's good for the local communities.

BARTIROMO: By the way, what's a small business? How do you identify that?

MILLER: Less than five million in revenues and 100 employees or less, so these are small businesses. This is the heart of America.

MCDOWELL: They have to be sitting there, though (INAUDIBLE) requirement to provide health insurance to go away which the government has yet to repeal the employer mandate, we got rid of individual mandate. Is that -- is that on their wish list and high on it?

MILLER: Listen, health care is the number one concern. It continues to be in every report. We survey and every survey we take of small business owners across the United States, it was number one concern, this time, too. So the cost of health care, the complexity and a lot of other things, so health care is definitely the top of the list.

BARTIROMO: By the way, they are using digital. They are not feeling the crypto craze, though, right? That's also something we should point out. There are two percent of small business owners believe crypto will be relevant to them but aren't sure how. Bitcoin has been all the buzz in Wall Street, obviously, in some quarters. It's not gaining traction for small business.

MILLER: No, it's not. It's not.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there, Sharon, great to see you.

MILLER: Thank you, great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us. We'll keep watching, Sharon Miller, joining us there. We'll take a break. When we come back, supporters of President Trump can get the boot from a bar, that's the ruling of a New York City judge, the outrage, coming up this morning. And then, forget dad jeans, Adidas is launching dad sneakers, but dad might walk away when he sees the price of these no frills kicks, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Big news from Ford Motor, the company putting a big part of its car business in the rear-view mirror. Cheryl Casone with the details now, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes. OK. So, if you like Ford Sedans, you better get one before they're all gone, Martha. Ford says that they're going to stop making the Fiesta sub-compact, the Fusion mid-sized Sedan, and the Tourist large Sedan. After that, Ford's only going to have two cars left in the line-up -- the mustang, of course, and a new hatchback of the focus active. The plan is to introduce more trucks and SUVs, which have been more popular with buyers, frankly. Shares of Ford are down about 12 percent so far this year.

Well, Chipotle is looking at options in an effort to try and turn around their business. Brian Nickel, who's the company's news CEO says that Chipotle is considering a few different things. Maybe they're going to franchise, maybe some new menu items, they're thinking about drive-throughs now. Shares up more than 10 percent in extended trading after their first- quarter results came in better than expected. The stock is up 15 percent so far this year. They're in recovery mode.

Well, get this. So, this is one of those only-in-New-York-stories. Supporters of President Trump can legally be thrown out of a bar because of their political beliefs, that's according to a Manhattan judge who ruled in favor of a that refuse to serve a man wearing a make America great hat. The judge says, current laws don't protect against political discrimination. This happened just after President Trump's inauguration. After the guy complained about room service, the Trump supporter says staff told him that he wasn't welcome there anymore, yes.

And then there's this, Adidas is getting into the dad shoe craze because, apparently, there's dad shoe craze out there. They have a new sneaker called the young one, which is reminiscent of the 1990s shoe. It's got a kind of a chunky design, the sole is thick, it's got suede, it's got nylon. This is basically all the rage right now, Maria. So, the retro shoe, if you want to pay the price, $130. So, to be a cool dad is not so cool and cheap, but there you have it.

BARTIROMO: Well, let's do a survey. We got some cool dads on the set right now.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Let's not get crazy.

(LAUGHTER)

HEGSETH: I mean, if you're wearing the dad shoe, I think you've given up on life. And it's not a good-looking shoe. I'm sorry, Adidas. I like Adidas. But all white is just too much for me.

BARTIROMO: OK. So, that's not a cool dad shoe. What do you think, James?

FREEMAN: I don't know. Wearing something that's specifically marketed as the dad shoe, I'm not sure just how cool that really would be, but -- I don't need it. I tend to avoid exercise.

MCDOWELL: If you have an injury -- a running injury, there's a brand of shoe called HOKA. Do you know what I'm talking about? H-O-K-A. They're big gigantic, chunky, and hideous. They're terrific athletic shoes and they're running shoes but they look kind of like that.

HEGSETH: Yes. Well, you don't have to choose to wear them.

MCDOWELL: They're great shoes, by the way. I was talking about the trend, ugly, expensive tennis shoe, I just found a pair of Balenciaga women's sneakers, they're only $900.

BARTIROMO: It's Balenciaga.

MCDOWELL: In case anybody has a bathtub full of cash and is really stupid.

BARTIROMO: We will take a break on that note. Coming up, the wait is finally over. It is NFL draft day on FOX. We're taking you inside the private NFL owners' meeting about national anthem protest. Sports, is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Lebron James does it again, another highlight to add to James' real. Jared Max with highlights. Wild night in NBA Playoffs last night, Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTS REPORTER: Maria, the Cavaliers and the Pacers were tied 2-2, in their first-round playoff series. Tied 95-95 under 10 seconds to play. Game five, Lebron, the stage is yours.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(CROWD CHEERING)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: James, two seconds, one second for the win.

(CHEERS AND APPLAUSE)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Lebron James delivers.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: Of course, Lebron scores 44, 15 to 15 from the foul line. The Pacers' Victor Oladipo said he should've -- gotten a goal-tending call at the other end. But you know, Lebron hit the three-point shot at the other end. Cavs up, 3-2.

Lebron, not the highest scorer in the NBA Playoffs last night. Russell Westbrook was -- he had 45. The Thunder trailed the Jazz by 25 points in the third quarter, and then outscored Utah, 61-28, over the final 20.5 minutes. They win by eight. Thunder still alive, down 3-2.

Former President George Herbert-Walker Bush has been moved out of an ICU unit into a regular hospital room, and he is focused on basketball. A statement released says, "President Bush naturally thanks everyone for their prayers and good wishes. He also wants to assure everyone that as good as he feels now, he's more focused on the Houston Rockets closing out their playoff series against the Minnesota Timberwolves than anything that landed him into the hospital." Well, President Bush should be smiling today. Houston Rockets won last night. They eliminated the Timberwolves in game five with ease, 122-104; 30 points for James Harden.

For the first time, we can say the NFL draft kicks off tonight on Fox 8:00 Eastern Time, AT&T stadium outside of Dallas, the draft will begin, the Cleveland Browns select Pete Hegseth -- no, you to tune in to see what it's going to be. The Browns have the first and the fourth picks.

The New York Times obtained an audio recording of a meeting that NFL owners and select players last fall, after President Trump suggested that any player who kneeled for national anthem should be fired, well, Bob Kraft, owner of New England Patriots, who's reported to have given President Trump a Super Bowl ring apparently isn't entirely on the president's side.

According to the New York Times, Kraft was reportedly recorded saying at the meeting: "The problem we have is, we have a president who will use that as fodder to do his mission that I don't feel is in the best interest of America." Robert Kraft says, "it's divisive and it's horrible." Over three hours of audio recordings coming out at that the New York Times have said to have listened to. You can imagine some of the comments that, you know, might've gone on in this meeting.

BARTIROMO: And this from a supporter. I mean, Bob Kraft has been supporter of the president.

HEGSETH: Yes, yes! I mean, the whole meeting was supposed to be confidential which, of course, never happens. I'm surprised here that Bob Kraft say that. He was one of those that you felt like was probably frustrated with the anthem protest and felt like the solution was to just stand for the anthem.

BARTIROMO: Right, he doesn't want lower ratings.

MCDOWELL: I can tell you one of the problems was though, is fewer and fewer players week after week were taking a knee during the national anthem. President Trump was still tweeting about it and drawing attention to it and trying to wit people into a frenzy over it, when it was less of a story if you were actually watching the game. And I think that the owners rightfully had problem with that.

MAX: Dagen, I think a lot of owners also found themselves in weird position because a game of politics, no pun intended, but here's something important from the president, but now they also have Rosters of 53. Jerry Jones found himself kneeling and then standing up -- almost like he didn't know what to do. All of a sudden, he was involved. So, not everybody -- it was a first time for everybody. Not that I'm giving him a pass, but I wonder why the Democrat --

HEGSETH: Yet it was (INAUDIBLE) in the off season. I mean, it still remains an issue, the NFL won't tackle and hasn't tackled yet.

BARTIROMO: Hey, has Colin Kaepernick gotten a job yet?

MAX: No. The Seahawks, maybe. Whoever is the 14th pick of the third round. Pie 3-14, gets free pizza for a year from Pizza Hut.

MCDOWELL: The problem with any owner taking Colin Kaepernick on at this point is he's got a divisive figure, and it's not just for the fans, it's even in the locker room -- it's a distraction.

MAX: You're paying more than $25.00 for baggage fees.

BARTIROMO: That's it, it's distraction.

MCDOWELL: You need to focus on the game. Again, the owners, what are you going to do? Tell all these men that they can't take a knee? And that essentially violates their first amendment rights, you can't do that.

BARTIROMO: Jared, thank you. Jared Max. Catch Jared's sports reports on Fox News Headlines 24/7 or in radio SiriusXM 115. Be sure to catch the NFL draft live coverage tonight 8:00 p.m. Eastern. First time Fox's aired the NFL draft coverage. Join us tonight, Fox NFL. Still ahead, adding A.I. to your children's ABC's. Amazon is launching a new version of Alexa for kids. The details on how it can teach them manners, next hour MORNINGS WITH MARIA, right here

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Thursday to you! It is Thursday, April 26th, your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. East Coast. Earnings in the driver seat on Wall Street this morning. That is what spectating stocks. The Dow Industrials expected to be up about 50 points right out of the gate, that's a quarter of a percent higher. The NASDAQ is up two-thirds of a percent right now.

END

urn:contentItem:5S66-RXC1-JB20-G3MY-00000-00Facebook's 1Q Beat; Comey Struggle to Defend Leaks; Celebrities Opening Up About Mental Illness; Small Business in America; Tax Reform Windfall; Ford To Drop Most Sedans; NYC Judge Rules Trump Supporters Can Be Refused Service; Adidas Launches Dad Shoe; Lebron's Buzzer Beater; OKC Erases 25-Point Deficit; 2018 NFL Draft2018-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:39ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTAlan Miller, Sharon MillerNEWSFinancial042601cb.231Facebook's 1Q Beat; Comey Struggle to Defend Leaks; Celebrities Opening Up About Mental Illness; Small Business in America; Tax Reform Windfall; Ford To Drop Most Sedans; NYC Judge Rules Trump Supporters Can Be Refused Service; Adidas Launches Dad Shoe; Lebron's Buzzer Beater; OKC Erases 25-Point Deficit; 2018 NFL DraftMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Pete Hegseth, Cheryl Casone, James Freeman, Jared Max

. MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Here there ladies, good morning to you. Thanks so much Gerri. Good morning, everybody, thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, April 26thm happy Thursday. Your top stories right now 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

It is the busiest single day of earnings season so far, industry giants like General Motors, Starbucks, Amazon, Microsoft all reporting their quarterly results today. Ahead of the earning splits, Futures indicating higher opening for the broader averages. Check it out, Dow Industrials up about 30 points right now, it's a fractional move on a percentage basis. So as is the S&P500, the NASDAQ right now, up half a percent, 33 points higher.

The Dow snapped a five-day losing streak yesterday lifted by Boeing's big earnings beat. Stock was strong. In yesterday's closing session, the Dow ended up 60 points, the S&P was up five, and the NASDAQ was down a fraction, three and a half points lower.

In Europe this morning, we've got gains across the board. Fractional move but the FT-100 is up 12, CAC Quarante in Paris is up 24 and the DAX Index up 21 points.

Investors are waiting on the European Central Bank decision this morning, that's due out in the next hour. No change in rates expected but the focus will be on the ECB President, Mario Draghi and his comments about the Future stimulus during his news conference. We'll bring you all the news from Europe coming up.

In Asia Overnight markets were mixed, the Shanghai Composite down one and a third percent, worst performer in China as you see.

And Facebook back on Wall Street's friends list, the stock soaring in the premarket this morning due to strong first quarter results showing an increase in daily users and monthly users despite the ongoing data scandal. The stock at 107 and change right now, we're breaking down those numbers, talk with Dan Niles, his number one position there coming up.

Another speed bump for Tesla to report, the new trouble for Elon Musk's electric automaker as the key member of the autopilot team departs amid new safety questions.

Then from flamethrowers to fire breathers, Elon Musk reveals his latest project, a cyborg dragon. The first details on the wild new robot coming up this morning.

And so you've got to look at benefits, you've got to look at all sights -- sorts of other things to attract the right workers into the small businesses.

FREEMAN: So, Sharon, we are seeing this surge in confidence and optimism among the business owners, but generally, we haven't seen, over the last year, a lot of loan growth or maybe not as much as we'd like to see, do you see that changing now or are there reasons why we shouldn't be concerned even if the loan growth isn't off the charts?

MILLER: Well, I think there's -- you know, there's different segments with loan growth. And so in the small business face Bank of America, we are seeing demand for lending. Our lending is strong and I would say that, you know, when small businesses get started, generally, they will start with either personal savings, perhaps a credit card, and then they are able to get more traditional financing.

We also partner with community development financial institutions for these small businesses that may not be eligible for traditional financing. But we are seeing demand both in our traditional lines and loans as well as our health care, so lending to dentists, doctors, veterinarians.

HEGSETH: Sharon, but not all small businesses are created equal, some sectors are struggling, may not feel optimism, where do you see the most optimism and what places are not?

MILLER: Well, I think, in the technology section, and certainly, there was a question in our survey that was all around, what do you think about digital payments? And half of our small business owners felt like over the next five years, that's all they would be taking.

So instead of checks and instead of the way we may pay traditionally today, especially to small business in the local (INAUDIBLE) landscaper, you know your dry cleaner. They are talking about all digital payments which is, you know, quite -- there's a trickle down there because there's people that have to build those types of capabilities.

BARTIROMO: So, you've got nearly one-third of all small businesses using smart phones --

MILLER: Yes.

BARTIROMO: to process digital payments, that's interesting. Are the small businesses having their access to credit? I mean, how is that going in terms of business getting the credit that they need? That was one issue that Linda McMahon brought up when she joined us, the Small Business Administrator, earlier in the week.

MILLER: Yes. And there is access to capital, I mean, that's something that we want to make sure they were out there, we're teaching people how to get access to capital and what you need to do when you're starting a small business, how you have to have revenues that are going to be able to repay that loan, so access to capital can come in more ways than just a traditional loan and there's education, there's training.

We are very focused on women, we just announced, last week, the Institute for Women's Entrepreneurship and Bank of America partnership with Cornell University, this is all about our attempt to make sure that we're giving the education, the training and the information necessary for people to get access to capital. Many people don't know how to do it.

BARTIROMO: So, compare women start-ups to male start-ups, what's higher?

MILLER: Women are starting businesses at twice the rate of men with half the capital. And so, it say, it's definitely a great opportunity for us to partner. We will be, in fact, at Times Square, this week. We are posting poster love for Small Business. We want to make sure that, you know, if you like a small business, go online, give a good review for them because that's going to help them in the local economy. So there's a lot of opportunity for us to support small businesses and it's good for the local communities.

BARTIROMO: By the way, what's a small business? How do you identify that?

MILLER: Less than five million in revenues and 100 employees or less, so these are small businesses. This is the heart of America.

MCDOWELL: They have to be sitting there, though (INAUDIBLE) requirement to provide health insurance to go away which the government has yet to repeal the employer mandate, we got rid of individual mandate. Is that -- is that on their wish list and high on it?

MILLER: Listen, health care is the number one concern. It continues to be in every report. We survey and every survey we take of small business owners across the United States, it was number one concern, this time, too. So the cost of health care, the complexity and a lot of other things, so health care is definitely the top of the list.

BARTIROMO: By the way, they are using digital. They are not feeling the crypto craze, though, right? That's also something we should point out. There are two percent of small business owners believe crypto will be relevant to them but aren't sure how. Bitcoin has been all the buzz in Wall Street, obviously, in some quarters. It's not gaining traction for small business.

MILLER: No, it's not. It's not.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there, Sharon, great to see you.

MILLER: Thank you, great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us. We'll keep watching, Sharon Miller, joining us there. We'll take a break. When we come back, supporters of President Trump can get the boot from a bar, that's the ruling of a New York City judge, the outrage, coming up this morning. And then, forget dad jeans, Adidas is launching dad sneakers, but dad might walk away when he sees the price of these no frills kicks, back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Big news from Ford Motor, the company putting a big part of its car business in the rear-view mirror. Cheryl Casone with the details now, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes. OK. So, if you like Ford Sedans, you better get one before they're all gone, Martha. Ford says that they're going to stop making the Fiesta sub-compact, the Fusion mid-sized Sedan, and the Tourist large Sedan. After that, Ford's only going to have two cars left in the line-up -- the mustang, of course, and a new hatchback of the focus active. The plan is to introduce more trucks and SUVs, which have been more popular with buyers, frankly. Shares of Ford are down about 12 percent so far this year.

Well, Chipotle is looking at options in an effort to try and turn around their business. Brian Nickel, who's the company's news CEO says that Chipotle is considering a few different things. Maybe they're going to franchise, maybe some new menu items, they're thinking about drive-throughs now. Shares up more than 10 percent in extended trading after their first- quarter results came in better than expected. The stock is up 15 percent so far this year. They're in recovery mode.

Well, get this. So, this is one of those only-in-New-York-stories. Supporters of President Trump can legally be thrown out of a bar because of their political beliefs, that's according to a Manhattan judge who ruled in favor of a that refuse to serve a man wearing a make America great hat. The judge says, current laws don't protect against political discrimination. This happened just after President Trump's inauguration. After the guy complained about room service, the Trump supporter says staff told him that he wasn't welcome there anymore, yes.

And then there's this, Adidas is getting into the dad shoe craze because, apparently, there's dad shoe craze out there. They have a new sneaker called the young one, which is reminiscent of the 1990s shoe. It's got a kind of a chunky design, the sole is thick, it's got suede, it's got nylon. This is basically all the rage right now, Maria. So, the retro shoe, if you want to pay the price, $130. So, to be a cool dad is not so cool and cheap, but there you have it.

BARTIROMO: Well, let's do a survey. We got some cool dads on the set right now.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Let's not get crazy.

(LAUGHTER)

HEGSETH: I mean, if you're wearing the dad shoe, I think you've given up on life. And it's not a good-looking shoe. I'm sorry, Adidas. I like Adidas. But all white is just too much for me.

BARTIROMO: OK. So, that's not a cool dad shoe. What do you think, James?

FREEMAN: I don't know. Wearing something that's specifically marketed as the dad shoe, I'm not sure just how cool that really would be, but -- I don't need it. I tend to avoid exercise.

MCDOWELL: If you have an injury -- a running injury, there's a brand of shoe called HOKA. Do you know what I'm talking about? H-O-K-A. They're big gigantic, chunky, and hideous. They're terrific athletic shoes and they're running shoes but they look kind of like that.

HEGSETH: Yes. Well, you don't have to choose to wear them.

MCDOWELL: They're great shoes, by the way. I was talking about the trend, ugly, expensive tennis shoe, I just found a pair of Balenciaga women's sneakers, they're only $900.

BARTIROMO: It's Balenciaga.

MCDOWELL: In case anybody has a bathtub full of cash and is really stupid.

BARTIROMO: We will take a break on that note. Coming up, the wait is finally over. It is NFL draft day on FOX. We're taking you inside the private NFL owners' meeting about national anthem protest. Sports, is next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Lebron James does it again, another highlight to add to James' real. Jared Max with highlights. Wild night in NBA Playoffs last night, Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTS REPORTER: Maria, the Cavaliers and the Pacers were tied 2-2, in their first-round playoff series. Tied 95-95 under 10 seconds to play. Game five, Lebron, the stage is yours.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(CROWD CHEERING)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: James, two seconds, one second for the win.

(CHEERS AND APPLAUSE)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Lebron James delivers.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: Of course, Lebron scores 44, 15 to 15 from the foul line. The Pacers' Victor Oladipo said he should've -- gotten a goal-tending call at the other end. But you know, Lebron hit the three-point shot at the other end. Cavs up, 3-2.

Lebron, not the highest scorer in the NBA Playoffs last night. Russell Westbrook was -- he had 45. The Thunder trailed the Jazz by 25 points in the third quarter, and then outscored Utah, 61-28, over the final 20.5 minutes. They win by eight. Thunder still alive, down 3-2.

Former President George Herbert-Walker Bush has been moved out of an ICU unit into a regular hospital room, and he is focused on basketball. A statement released says, "President Bush naturally thanks everyone for their prayers and good wishes. He also wants to assure everyone that as good as he feels now, he's more focused on the Houston Rockets closing out their playoff series against the Minnesota Timberwolves than anything that landed him into the hospital." Well, President Bush should be smiling today. Houston Rockets won last night. They eliminated the Timberwolves in game five with ease, 122-104; 30 points for James Harden.

For the first time, we can say the NFL draft kicks off tonight on Fox 8:00 Eastern Time, AT&T stadium outside of Dallas, the draft will begin, the Cleveland Browns select Pete Hegseth -- no, you to tune in to see what it's going to be. The Browns have the first and the fourth picks.

The New York Times obtained an audio recording of a meeting that NFL owners and select players last fall, after President Trump suggested that any player who kneeled for national anthem should be fired, well, Bob Kraft, owner of New England Patriots, who's reported to have given President Trump a Super Bowl ring apparently isn't entirely on the president's side.

According to the New York Times, Kraft was reportedly recorded saying at the meeting: "The problem we have is, we have a president who will use that as fodder to do his mission that I don't feel is in the best interest of America." Robert Kraft says, "it's divisive and it's horrible." Over three hours of audio recordings coming out at that the New York Times have said to have listened to. You can imagine some of the comments that, you know, might've gone on in this meeting.

BARTIROMO: And this from a supporter. I mean, Bob Kraft has been supporter of the president.

HEGSETH: Yes, yes! I mean, the whole meeting was supposed to be confidential which, of course, never happens. I'm surprised here that Bob Kraft say that. He was one of those that you felt like was probably frustrated with the anthem protest and felt like the solution was to just stand for the anthem.

BARTIROMO: Right, he doesn't want lower ratings.

MCDOWELL: I can tell you one of the problems was though, is fewer and fewer players week after week were taking a knee during the national anthem. President Trump was still tweeting about it and drawing attention to it and trying to wit people into a frenzy over it, when it was less of a story if you were actually watching the game. And I think that the owners rightfully had problem with that.

MAX: Dagen, I think a lot of owners also found themselves in weird position because a game of politics, no pun intended, but here's something important from the president, but now they also have Rosters of 53. Jerry Jones found himself kneeling and then standing up -- almost like he didn't know what to do. All of a sudden, he was involved. So, not everybody -- it was a first time for everybody. Not that I'm giving him a pass, but I wonder why the Democrat --

HEGSETH: Yet it was (INAUDIBLE) in the off season. I mean, it still remains an issue, the NFL won't tackle and hasn't tackled yet.

BARTIROMO: Hey, has Colin Kaepernick gotten a job yet?

MAX: No. The Seahawks, maybe. Whoever is the 14th pick of the third round. Pie 3-14, gets free pizza for a year from Pizza Hut.

MCDOWELL: The problem with any owner taking Colin Kaepernick on at this point is he's got a divisive figure, and it's not just for the fans, it's even in the locker room -- it's a distraction.

MAX: You're paying more than $25.00 for baggage fees.

BARTIROMO: That's it, it's distraction.

MCDOWELL: You need to focus on the game. Again, the owners, what are you going to do? Tell all these men that they can't take a knee? And that essentially violates their first amendment rights, you can't do that.

BARTIROMO: Jared, thank you. Jared Max. Catch Jared's sports reports on Fox News Headlines 24/7 or in radio SiriusXM 115. Be sure to catch the NFL draft live coverage tonight 8:00 p.m. Eastern. First time Fox's aired the NFL draft coverage. Join us tonight, Fox NFL. Still ahead, adding A.I. to your children's ABC's. Amazon is launching a new version of Alexa for kids. The details on how it can teach them manners, next hour MORNINGS WITH MARIA, right here

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Thursday to you! It is Thursday, April 26th, your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. East Coast. Earnings in the driver seat on Wall Street this morning. That is what spectating stocks. The Dow Industrials expected to be up about 50 points right out of the gate, that's a quarter of a percent higher. The NASDAQ is up two-thirds of a percent right now.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XR6-DT01-F00X-J2GR-00000-00Facebook's 3 Biggest Challenges in 20202019-12-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:38ZLexisNexisFacebook's 3 Biggest Challenges in 2020Annie Gaus

Political and regulatory pressures, content moderation and developing fresh revenue sources are some of the key hurdles facing Facebook next year.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said it himself: 2020 is going to be a tough year for the company.

Zuckerberg said as much on Facebook third quarter earnings call, when he told investors that over the next year, with the 2020 Presidential race ramping up, Facebook could be any time there's a partisan political conflict, potentially generating renewed criticism and even further investigations of the company. Facebook shares are up 49% so far this year.

Political matters aren't the only challenge facing Facebook in 2020 however. Below are some of the key themes to watch next year.


1. New Revenue Sources

Facebook's core newsfeed isn't the crown jewel of its portfolio anymore, at least where its next wave of growth is concerned. Instagram and Stories, and even WhatsApp, are looking a lot more interesting these days to many growth-seeking investors.

Accordingly, Facebook's advertising products are evolving. Stories have evolved into a popular medium for sharing content among friends, both on Facebook and Instagram, and advertisers are beginning to better understand how to monetize these emerging forms of communication on Facebook. Interest in Stories will likely remain high next year, and Facebook will need to meet investor expectations on that front.

Although it's nascent, there is hope among investors that shopping and commerce will turn into a meaningful source of revenue, particularly on Instagram and WhatsApp. Analysts have noted that Instagram, as a visual-first medium that's increasingly popular among advertisers, is a natural fit for shopping. In November, Facebook , a PayPal-esque peer-to-peer payments system that, if widely adopted, could make shopping through Facebook easier -- and potentially boost monetization potential across all of Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp.


2. Problem Content

Ever since Cambridge Analytica, Facebook has taken pains to inform people how its processes for purging fishy accounts, apps and other types of problematic content are improving. Recently, it said in a blog post that it removed 3.2 billion fake accounts in It also broke out for the first time its content moderation efforts on Instagram versus core Facebook, saying that it deleted millions of pieces of content depicting child abuse and self-harm.

Progress on content moderation is a good thing, but it also doesn't come cheap. Facebook spends in the ballpark of $5 billion per year on safety, security and content moderation efforts, and that cost isn't likely to come down significantly anytime soon. On its third quarter earnings call, Zuckerberg told investors that "I don't foresee any time in the near future that AI is going to make it so that the cost comes down...there's just so much content flowing through the system that we do need a lot of people looking at this. And I don't think that's going to change anytime soon."

Relying on humans for content moderation comes with its own host of problems. Months ago, an investigation by The Verge into poor working conditions of Facebook contractors who moderate content sparked a stiff backlash. It's also an imperfect system, a game of whack-a-mole that will likely remain a liability for Facebook well into the future.


3. Regulatory Headaches

Facebook's Libra project was supposed to represent its next big innovation in financial services. Instead, it became a flash point for long-simmering ire towards the company for privacy-related infractions, political advertising, content moderation issues, and even its spotty record on civil rights. In two separate hearings, one with Facebook executive David Marcus and the other with CEO Mark Zuckberberg, lawmakers vented their frustrations with the social media firm's impact on society.

It's uncertain what form Libra will take when, or if, it launches as initially planned in 2020. If it does launch, it'll likely be a drastically scaled-down version of Facebook's original vision of a global digital currency with a large network of partners; after being told by lawmakers they could bear liability for problems with Libra, several major partners, such as PayPal and Mastercard , withdrew their participation.

Beyond just Libra, however, regulators in the U.S. and elsewhere are keeping their eyes on Facebook. Facebook is one of several big tech companies facing an antitrust review by the DOJ, FTC and nearly all , likely focusing on its data practices, acquisitions, and product development. In Europe, it faces potentially even greater pressures, including scrutiny into hate speech, stiff potential penalties for GDPR violations, and a new antitrust probe by the European Commission. Next year, it will have to reassure investors that regulatory pressures won't negatively impact its long-term prospects.
