urn:contentItem:5TM7-H3W1-F03R-N47S-00000-00Facebook's 3Q Growth Suffices to Stave Off Another Stock Dive2018-10-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:38ZLexisNexisFacebook's 3Q Growth Suffices to Stave Off Another Stock DiveBernadette Tansey

Oct 31, 2018( Xconomy: http://www.xconomy.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Facebook (NASDAQ: FB[1]) shares gained nearly 3 percent Tuesday, and ticked up further in after-hours trading following the release of a third quarter earnings report[2] that showed some strengths as well as shortfalls. Investors have been concerned about the social media giant's slowing growth rate in a year when it has been under scrutiny for data privacy violations and its role in the spread of false and divisive messages by fake user accounts traced to Russian agents during U.S. election campaigns.On the strength side of the third quarter report: The company's profit of $5.14 billion, or $1.76 per share, exceeded Wall Street expectations, Reuters reported[3]. Although the number of daily users remained flat at 185 million in the United States and Canada, the company saw a rise of a million monthly users for the region.But Menlo Park, CA-based Facebook's revenue growth followed the pattern of deceleration the company had foretold as it released its second quarter[4] numbers in July, when the market reacted by stripping more than $100 billion from its market capitalization. In the third quarter, revenue rose 33 percent to $13.7 billion compared to the same period a year ago. But that was a decline from the revenue growth rate of 42 percent for the second quarter of this year.The third quarter brought Facebook the loss of a million users in Europe, where strict new data privacy regulations are giving users more control over the personal data collected and shared, and where government investigators have faulted the company for allowing third-party developers to extract user profiles without their consent.

The U.K.'s data privacy regulatorfined Facebook[5]$645,000 last week for violations that allowed 87 million user profiles to fall into the hands of outside companies, including political marketing firm Cambridge Analytica.In September, Facebook counted an average of 1.49 billion daily active users—a 9 percent rise compared to the preceding year and an advance over the 1.47 billion reported for June. However, Facebook is seeing the most growth in geographic regions that bring in the least revenue. The average revenue per user in the U.S. and Canada is $27.61; in Europe, it's $8.82. For the Asian Pacific user, revenue is $2.67, and users in the rest of the world bring in an average of $1.82.'We may be close to saturation in developed countries while we continue to see growth in less developed countries,' Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said in an earnings conference call Tuesday.Zuckerberg and other executives outlined a number of shifts and transitions that mark this period in Facebook's business trajectory. For one thing, the company has been increasing its expenditures to beef up security and reform its privacy practices. Zuckerberg said the company had lagged behind in such efforts in prior years, and added that he expects it won't be until the end of next year before 'we're as dialed in as we'd like to be.' But he said Facebook is making progress through measures like deploying artificial intelligence software to flag problem content such as terrorist messages and hate speech.Facebook is also trying to move users and advertisers into new formats that don't yet yield as much advertising revenue as its news feeds on Facebook and Instagram. The company is trying to foster growth in messaging and a style of social media sharing known as 'stories,' in which people describe moments in their lives. Facebook is working with advertisers to design ads to blend in with these formats, which Zuckerberg says encourage more social interaction than activities like watching viral videos that don't necessarily reflect the core interests of users.The earnings news comes as Facebook is under a number of other pressures:—The U.K. government announced a new 'digital services tax' of 2 percent on the revenues drawn from the U.K. by search engines, social media platforms, and online marketplaces that make more than $638 million globally, MIT Technology Review reported[6]. The tax, set to take effect in 2020, might inspire other jurisdictions such as the European Union to impose similar levies.—When U.K. regulators last week fined Facebook $645,000, it was for violations of older privacy codes. But future fines for similar violations under the nation's new privacy laws could far exceed that. Under the U.K.'s Data Protection Act 2018 and the EU's stringent General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), companies that violate data privacy protection requirements can be fined as much as $21.7 million, or 4 percent of a company's annual global revenue.—Shareholders have been benefiting from Facebook's ability to generate billions in ad revenue by offering advertisers the ability to target ads to selected portions of the population, based on the personal data Facebook has collected about them. But this year, Facebook has lost market cap as well as user growth in high-revenue regions such as Europe and the United States, as its impact on privacy and the public discourse of nations draws increasing scrutiny. And some shareholders are calling the company on the carpet.This week, impact investor Arjuna Capital[7] and New York State's big pension fund filed a shareholder proposal[8] calling on Facebook to lay out in writing how it plans to fend off data breaches and fake users, while better guarding its network from being used to spread misinformation, incite hatred, improperly interfere with elections, and suppress legitimate free speech.New York State Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli joined Arjuna in the shareholder filing, acting as trustee of the New York State Common Retirement Fund, which manages the retirement accounts of more than a million state and local government employees and retirees. The fund, which managed assets of $209.2 billion as of June 30, is the third largest U.S. public pension fund. Based on the fund's figures, the pension fund lost roughly $257 million due to the drop in the value of Facebook's shares since the beginning of the year.—An overall bear market: Since Oct. 1, the Nasdaq composite index is down about 12 percent, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average has fallen about 8 percent.Photo 'Money!' by Flickr user Tracy O[9]. urn:contentItem:5WJF-T4S1-JCJY-G3MX-00000-00Facebook's $5 billion fine for privacy violations is slammed as a 'slap on the wrist' by critics as company's share prices RISES after news2019-07-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:38ZLexisNexisNEWSVersion:9Facebook's $5 billion fine for privacy violations is slammed as a 'slap on the wrist' by critics as company's share prices RISES after newsAssociated Press

The Federal Trade Commission has voted to approve a fine of about $5 billion for Facebook over privacy violations

The 3-2 vote broke along party lines, with Republicans in support and Democrats in opposition to the fine

The FTC report has been moved to the Justice Department for review. It is not clear how long it will take to finalize

The fine would be the largest the FTC has levied on a tech company - but it will do little to dent the reserves of Facebook, who made $56 billion last year

Facebook shares finished the day UP 1.8 per cent, at $204.87.

The Federal Trade Commission has voted to fine Facebook a record-breaking $5 billion following a long-running investigation into the tech giant's repeated failure's to protect its users' privacy, the Wall Street Journal reported on Friday.

With the motion passed by a vote of 3-2, FTC's decision broke party lines, with the Republican majority voicing support of the fine, while Democratic commissioners voice objections.

Facebook was fined in connection over its deal with now-defunct British political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica where private information belonging to 87 million people was shared inappropriately.

The $5bn fine is the largest penalty against a tech firm, but shares in the company jumped up by 1.8 percent following the announcement - as investors expected the punishment could have been more severe.

Several Democrats claimed the punishment was a slap on the wrist.

Democrat representative David Cicilline, who is chair of a congressional antitrust panel, called the $5 billion penalty 'a Christmas present five months early'.

He said: 'This fine is a fraction of Facebook's annual revenue. It won't make them think twice about their responsibility to protect user data.'

The tech giant's revenue for the first quarter of 2019 was $15.1bn, while the company is worth an estimated $585billion.

The next stages will be handled by the Justice Department's civil division, though for now it remains unclear how long it will take to finalize.

According to WSJ sources, the vote will be reviewed by the Justice Department, as required by protocol, but it's incredibly the verdict will be reversed.

For now, the specifics of the settlement remain largely unknown, except for the figure which is believed to be in the region of $5 billion.

Once finalized, the fine will become the largest ever levied on a tech company, but it won't make much of a dent in Facebook's reserves, which registered more than $56 billion in revenue last year alone.

But the deal may also include other government restrictions on how Facebook handles and regulates user privacy.

Regardless, investors did not seem overly concerned with the news - and Facebook shares finished the day up 1.8 per cent, at $204.87.

The divide between Republicans and Democrats on the matter was irked in large by the latter pushing for tougher oversight of Facebook in addition to the fine.

The FTC's investigation into Facebook began more than a year ago, after the data of millions of users of the social media site wound up in the possession of Cambridge Analytica, a firm assisting with Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.

The Cambridge Analytica breach came as one of many leaks for the social-media giant, only adding to the FTC's grievances.

It also acknowledged giving big tech companies like Amazon and Yahoo extensive access to users' personal data, in effect exempting them from its usual privacy rules

In response, Facebook has since repeatedly vowed to do a better job corralling its users' data, but fell short of FTC expectations.

Facebook and other prominent tech companies finds themselves under increasing scrutiny in Washington DC.

On Thursday, the capital held a 'social media summit' at the White House where President Trump voiced particular disdain about Silicon Valley and its perceived disfavoring of conservatives.

Facebook wasn't invited to the event, neither were other tech companies.

The Zuckerburg founded site claim to police their platforms regardless of political ideology.

urn:contentItem:5SWK-SN41-F03R-N4NP-00000-00Facebook's active user growth went into reverse for the first time, and the worst is yet to come (FB)2018-07-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:38ZLexisNexisFacebook's active user growth went into reverse for the first time, and the worst is yet to come (FB)Shona Ghosh

Jul 26, 2018( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Getty Facebook saw a decline in monthly active users for the first time in its history. It's a big deal because the decline was in Europe, which has just introduced the strict new GDPR privacy regulation. It shows that regulation is capable of curtailing Facebook's massive growth and capping its revenue. The worst is yet to come because the full impact of GDPR is yet to kick in.

Facebook saw a decline inmonthly active users for the first time in its history, the company reported during its dramatic second-quarter earnings on Wednesday. Any decline is significant and bad news for a company generally considered to be a rocket ship of growth. But what should cause some alarm is where the decline happened, and whether it will get worse. According to Facebook, European monthly active users dropped by 1 million between the first and second quarters, falling from 377 million to 376 million.It's the only region where Facebook saw declines, with the biggest region, Asia-Pacific, jumping from 873 million users to 894 million users. The US stayed flat quarter over quarter at 241 million monthly active users. Facebook blamed the decline on "currency headwinds" and Europe's new privacy-focused regulation, the GDPR. "GDPR was an important moment for our industry," CEO Mark Zuckerberg told analysts. "We did see a decline in monthly actives in Europe, down by about 1 million people as a result." GDPR was specifically designed to bring the big tech firms to heel, and regulates how companies use people's data[1]. Executives noticeably dodged talking about the ongoing impact of GDPR beyond the second quarter. "[We] don't have any update on trends," said Wehner. "We had indicated in the first quarter that we would expect to see a decline. We're not providing any guidance on [monthly active users] and [daily active users] in Europe on this call." There are multiple signs that Europe won't recover.Europe only rolled out its new privacy rules in late May — so Facebook will continue to feel its impact into the next quarterGDPR only kicked in on May 25, two-thirds of the way through Facebook's second quarter. Facebook began showing its privacy notifications around May 24 in order to comply with the new rules.[2] Facebook's thesis is that these notifications turned off its European users, who then spent less time on the platform and have perhaps become more privacy-conscious. Given that GDPR only impacted some of Facebook's second quarter, there could be knock-on effects in the third quarter. The decline shows that Facebook, which seemed to be infallible, isn't completely invincible against regulation. And whether Facebook is even properly complying with GDPR is under some contention[3]. At the moment, Facebook tells users who don't share certain types of data that they won't be able to use parts of its platform. That goes against the spirit of GDPR, which says companies can't penalise users for not sharing information. As Pivotal analyst Brian Wieser put it: "Our view is that the company is far from 'out of the woods' as the bundling of consent for Facebook to use consumer data with access to the platform appears to be an aggressive interpretation of GDPR, and one that might be more subject to eventual regulatory action. "While those actions might take time to play out, it is still possible that threatened fines associated with GDPR to Facebook or other sellers of advertising could also have the effect of spooking advertisers into changing how they use data with media owners." In other words, a court could find that Facebook hasn't complied with GDPR, fine the company, and then force even stricter privacy measures that impact its European user base even more.Losing money and users in its second-biggest market would be very bad news for FacebookEurope has, up until now, been an extremely stable market for Facebook. It's the second biggest by active users, behind Asia-Pacific, and the second biggest in how much money the company makes per user, behind the US. This is how much Facebook makes per user in its biggest markets: US: $25.91 Europe: $8.76 Asia: $2.62That's why Europe, despite being smaller than Asia-Pacific by user numbers, actually brought in more revenue. Europe made $3.3 billion in revenue, versus $2.3 billion from Asia.This is why any sign of decline in Europe is so drastic. While revenue and average revenue per user looks intact for now, any sign of cratering engagement will scare advertisers away from Facebook's core platform. Facebook appears to know that, with COO Sheryl Sandberg noting that advertisers were still adapting to the new rules. "GDPR has not had a revenue impact, but we also recognize it wasn't fully rolled out this quarter," she told analysts. "It was very encouraging for us to see that the vast majority of people affirmed that they want us to use information, including from the websites they visit, to make their ads more relevant. But, as we look further out, we recognize that there's still risk, and we're going to watch closely."NOW WATCH: What people get wrong about superfoods[4]See Also: Instagram is booming, and investors are salivating over Facebook as a result[5]China has withdrawn approval for Facebook's new venture in the country, where it remains banned[6]'Marvel Powers United' is unlike any other VR game you've played before[7] [ 1]: http://uk.businessinsider.com/what-is-gdpr-regulation-explained-2018-4?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 2]:   http://uk.businessinsider.com/what-facebook-updates-and-settings-review-means-2018-4?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 3]:   https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/may/25/facebook-google-gdpr-complaints-eu-consumer-rights [ 4]:   https://www.businessinsider.com/what-people-get-wrong-about-superfoods-nutrition-health-acai-goji-turmeric-quinoa-2018-6?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 5]:   https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-q2-earnings-preview-what-to-expect-instagram-2018-7?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 6]:   https://www.businessinsider.com/chinese-government-withdraws-approval-facebook-subsidiary-2018-7?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 7]:   https://www.businessinsider.com/oculus-marvel-powers-united-thanos-black-panther-captain-america-deadpool-2018-7?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WS6-N1J1-JDPH-B026-00000-00Facebook's addictive ability to cause harm has parallels with Big Tobacco: David Richards2019-08-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:38ZLexisNexisFacebook's addictive ability to cause harm has parallels with Big Tobacco: David RichardsDavid Richards

Big Tech is the new Big Tobacco. For decades, the tobacco industry denied that smoking causes lung cancer, that nicotine is addictive and that it targets the young.

In public, the industry presented itself as the supplier of a legal product used by responsible adults for a widely enjoyed social habit. But behind the scenes, this was a predatory industry engaged in what campaigners Clive Bates and Andy Rowell have described as "the most astonishing systematic corporate deceit of all time".

Yet its ability to cause public harm pales in comparison to a new threat of unprecedented size and scale that has emerged in recent years, one that we are only just beginning to understand: social media and specifically its negative impact on the mental health of its users.

Facebook criticised for domination of digital revenues

I am the founder, CEO and chairman of WANdisco plc, a public software company jointly headquartered in Silicon Valley and Sheffield, and I have spent two decades at the leading edge of the technology industry.

It saddens me that some of the finest minds of my generation have applied themselves to the creation of a purposefully addictive platform that I'm convinced is driving a new mental health epidemic.

With nearly three billion active users, it is even bigger than Big Tobacco. The UK government seems to be waking up to the dangers and has just finished consulting on its Online Harms White Paper, which includes plans to crack down on terrorist propaganda, child abuse and bullying online through the creation of a new regulator. I believe we need to go further and look at the effects of social media per se on mental health and wellbeing, especially among young people.

Most of us have family members and friends who have suffered mental health problems, either caused or made worse by social media. Even Facebook has questioned whether simply spending time on social media might be bad for our mental health.

Why posting about Brexit on Facebook and Twitter could get you in trouble with the police

Mark Zuckerberg's colossus had its own Big Tobacco moment in late 2017 when billionaire early investor Sean Parker admitted that Facebook's inventors consciously exploited a vulnerability in human psychology. "God only knows what it's doing to our children's brains," he said.

The Government has an absolute duty to find out.

Ministers might have attracted headlines with their White Paper, but Big Tech, like Big Tobacco, has an army of well-connected and expensive lobbyists, including the former UK Deputy Prime Minister Sir Nick Clegg, who will be working to influence parliament to protect their lucrative business model and water down any proposals in the name of safeguarding innovation, the digital economy and freedom of speech.

Let us be aware of the damage that is being done. According to the Royal Society for Public Health, 91 per cent of 16 to 24-year-olds use the internet for social networking; social media has been described as more addictive than cigarettes and alcohol; rates of anxiety and depression in young people have risen 70 per cent in the past 25 years; social media use is linked with increased rates of anxiety, depression and poor sleep; and cyber bullying is a growing problem with seven in 10 young people saying they have experienced it.

Regulation is a positive first step in combating these problems but in the case of Big Tobacco, it hasn't stopped smoking from killing an estimated seven million people every year. In spite of everything we now know about smoking, Big Tobacco still wields enormous power and remains a global player with a base of more than one billion customers across the world.

Like Big Tobacco, Big Tech has a closely guarded business model, which generates billions of dollars in profits. It uses legal loopholes to reduce its tax liabilities. It pleads freedom but evades its responsibilities.

Its business activities place strain on our cash-strapped NHS.

We need more research into the correlation between social media and mental health and through the David and Jane Richards Family Foundation, our computer science and ecology charity, we are prepared to help fund it.

It is time we fully understood the true impact that Big Tech's platforms and secretive algorithms are having on young minds, for the sake of everyone's future.

David Richards is the founder and chief executive of Sheffield-based technology company WANdisco. For more details about the David and Jane Richards Family Foundation, visit www.djrff.org

urn:contentItem:5RWB-VS61-JCMN-Y050-00000-00Facebook's adding another Frank Gehry building to its Silicon Valley campus as part of a $303 million project (FB)2018-03-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:38ZLexisNexisFacebook's adding another Frank Gehry building to its Silicon Valley campus as part of a $303 million project (FB)Katie Canales

Mar 15, 2018( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) REUTERS/Noah Berger Facebook, whose headquarters was designed by Frank Gehry, is planning to add another building designed by the star architect to its Silicon Valley campus. The company plans to demolish five older buildings to make way for the new one. The total project, which will also include a park and a sky bridge to connect the new building with another one, is estimated to cost $303 million.

Facebook's Silicon Valley campus will soon include another building designed by star architect Frank Gehry. The social networking giant filed permits last month to begin construction of the four-story, 464,000-square-foot building at its Menlo Park, California, headquarters. As part of the development, Facebook plans to demolish five other buildings and construct a 3500-spot parking garage. The company has already begun demolishing those buildings, spokesman Jamil Walker said in an email. Walker also confirmed thepermit applications, which were originally uncovered by BuildZoom[1], a web service that keeps tabs on construction permits and offers building contractor recommendations. Menlo Park's City Council approved Facebook's overall plan for the site in November, Walker noted. "We value the ongoing partnership with the community as we work together to revitalize an aging industrial site and speed up the delivery of the community benefits promised in our development agreement," Walker said. The plan includes a new open space, he said. Facebook also plans to build a bridge that will connect a neighborhood just south of its campus to San Francisco Bay, which is just to its north, he said. The new Gehry-designed building, dubbed Building 22 or MPK 22, will be constructed on the western portion of Facebook's campus one its permit is issued. Facebook estimated the project would cost $303 million, not including furniture and equipment for the building. The plan includes a sky bridge that will connect the new building to the campus' Building 21. That building, which is already under construction, and the main headquarters building on the campus were also designed by Gehry, who is best known for his stainless steel-clad curvilinear buildings, including Los Angeles' Walt Disney Concert Hall and the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao in Spain. One of the five buildings Facebook plans to demolish will remain standing until it completes Building 22. After the new building is completed, Facebook will replace the old one with a park and recharging facilities for Facebook's shuttle buses and trams.NOW WATCH: How a woman from the 1800s became the first computer programmer[2]See Also: Here's why you should stop using Venmo, and start using Facebook Messenger for paying back your friends[3]London mayor Sadiq Khan ripped into big tech over fake news, online abuse, and regulatory arbitrage[4]Facebook removed a new Android security app that critics said unfairly collects private data[5] SEE ALSO:Facebook is building a village that will include housing, a grocery store and a hotel[6] [ 1]: https://www.buildzoom.com/property-info/1-facebook-way-menlo-park-ca?utm_swu=5285..._medium=email..._source=reporter..._campaign=permits [ 2]:   http://www.businessinsider.com/worlds-first-computer-programmer-2018-3?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 3]:   http://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-messenger-venmo-pay-friends-2018-3?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 4]:   http://www.businessinsider.com/sadiq-khan-criticised-facebook-twitter-uber-google-fake-news-abuse-2018-3?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 5]:   http://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-onavo-removes-bolt-lock-from-google-play-store-2018-3?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 6]:   http://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-building-employee-housing-silicon-valley-headquarters-2017-7?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y2M-MGY1-JC3H-01PF-00000-00Facebook's ad policy is a threat to US elections2020-01-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A7Facebook's ad policy is a threat to US electionsByYour TurnGuest columnist

The day after Facebook's enforcement czar Monika Bickert told Congress about Facebook's efforts to prevent the spread of misinformation on the platform, the company was reaffirming that Facebook would allow campaigns to buy political ads that make provably false statements.

This policy is a clear and present danger to American democracy.

First, let's remember that Facebook is not just another outlet for the distribution of advertising content. As Bickert pointed out in her Jan. 8 statement to an Energy and Commerce subcommittee, "Facebook is a community of more than 2 billion people, spanning countries, cultures and languages across the globe." That's a quarter of the world's population.

The firm has massive monopoly power to influence public opinion.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg claims that Facebook has adopted this policy because it is committed to protecting "free expression," and that the company should not be the arbiter of truth.

In fact, this policy has nothing to do with protecting free expression. Instead, it is aimed at letting Facebook make hundreds of millions of dollars showing ads on its platform, even if they're untrue.

Under his policy, for instance, Facebook would presumably allow a candidate to spend hundreds of millions of dollars claiming that his or her opponent ran a pedophile ring in a pizza parlor in Washington, D.C. That outrageous conspiracy theory actually circulated widely about Hillary Clinton in right-wing circles before the last election - but was never circulated as paid advertising. Now, Facebook is saying that if you want to spend a fortune to promote that conspiracy, they are happy to take your money.

In response, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi excoriated Facebook: "They have said very blatantly, very clearly that they intend to be accomplices for misleading the American people with money from God knows where."

It is true that under federal law, internet platforms like Facebook are not liable for what third parties post on their sites. But Facebook still reserves the right to remove posts that violate its rules, or so-called community standards. In fact, it does serve the cause of free speech for those who post on platforms like Facebook to be subject only to the same limitations on speech that our legal system has determined apply in other arenas of life.

People should be able to speak freely about their views - but should not be allowed to advocate violence or to cry "fire" in a crowded theater, because the exercise of that free speech right impinges on other critical rights. As things stands now, however, the same does not apply to Facebook when it takes money from a person or organization to advertise their points of view. Once Facebook takes money to promote a candidate or cause, the company becomes an agent of the campaign or organization promoting that message. And once it is an agent of a campaign or cause, it should be held responsible and liable for ads that contain provable lies.

Facebook should be held to the same standards as TV networks like CNN and CBS, since it is really exactly the same kind of broadcast service.

Its refusal to do so opens a massive opportunity for conspiracy theorists and demagogues to spend fortunes promoting provably false allegations with absolute impunity. And the sad fact is that if even the most outrageous lie is repeated often enough, large numbers of people will come to believe it. Donald Trump understands that.

Zuckerberg is increasingly concerned about the growing movement to regulate and break up big tech, especially virtual monopolies like Facebook. The president could do a lot to protect Zuckerberg's empire - especially if he is reelected. Democratic candidates like Sen. Elizabeth Warren, who have openly advocated breaking up Facebook and other big tech companies, cause Zuckerberg special concern.

All of that makes you wonder what was said in Zuckerberg's private dinner with Trump last fall at the White House.

It is impossible to overstate the danger that Facebook's policy poses to American democracy. It opens up a gigantic breach in the bulwark of our democratic institutions - and to the integrity of the next election.

Ordinary citizens need to take matters into their own hands. That's why a number of major progressive organizations are considering a nationwide petition campaign to demand that Facebook refuse to run advertising that contains objectively false statements. We need to join them.

Robert Creamer, a partner at Democracy Partners, has been a political organizer and strategist for five decades and was a consultant in the last three Democratic presidential campaigns. He is the author of "Listen to Your Mother: Stand Up Straight: How Progressives Can Win."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WCD-S8S1-DXH2-627N-00000-00Facebook's Announces New Cryptocurrency Libra, Expected to Launch in 2020; Big Business of Lego2019-06-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:39ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTLindsey Bell, McLaughlin, Jacek Olczak, David Marcus, Julia GoldinNEWSDomestic061802cb.231Facebook's Announces New Cryptocurrency Libra, Expected to Launch in 2020; Big Business of LegoMaria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Lauren Simonetti

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us live from Cannes this morning.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Tuesday, June 18th.

Your top stories right now at just 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast on the button.

Facebook's crypto, the social media giant creates a new digital currency, sending the stock up in the premarket. I'll bet talking live his morning to the head of the new cryptocurrency later this hour. Plus, find out the major companies already on-board with this. Stock is up better than 2 percent.

Markets are higher this morning. Take a look at futures, indicating a higher opening for the broader market ahead of a two-day Federal Reserve meeting. The Dow Industrials now at the high of the morning, up 114 points, S&P futures up 15, and the Nasdaq futures are up 68 points.

The fed is beginning its meeting today. We are going to be scrutinizing what the Fed says tomorrow, 2:15 Eastern when we get the news from Jay Powell. We're not expecting a rate cut tomorrow but we are expecting some language to suggest maybe we get one later on in the year.

There's yesterday's close, also firmer. DowIndustrials were up 23 points, S&P was up 2 points and the Nasdaq was up 48 percent. Communications stocks, energy stocks really drove the move yesterday.

In Europe this morning, money is moving into stocks there as well. Take a look at European indices across the board higher. FT 100 up 57 points, three-quarters of a percent. CAC 40 in Paris up 1.5 percent, 75 points. Dax Index in Germany up 1.25 percent, that is 148 points higher.

In Asia overnight, Hong Kong did well. Take a look at the Asian indices. It was mostly higher with the exception of Japan. Hang Seng was up 1 percent after all of those protests. We've got more on that this morning as well.

Meanwhile, tourist deaths, a New Jersey man is the latest to die in the Dominican Republic. This story is a mystery. And we are going to be digging deep into what has gone on.

Then dozens of Jimmy Buffet fans claimed they were sickened during their trip. Take a look.

Trouble for Boeing this morning, the aircraft maker recording no new plane orders at the Paris air show. Meanwhile, you've got competitors seeing blood and upping up their game.

Then the frightening video of a flight hitting major turbulence. All that coming up.

Plus a real life iron man. Check this out. A look at the bulletproof suit that has been built and it can actually fly. Find out who made it.

All those stories coming up this Tuesday morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Cheryl Casone in New York along with CFRA investment strategist Lindsey Bell.

Ladies, good to see you this morning.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning -- Maria.

I'll tell you what. The Fed's two-day meeting is starting, oil isn't higher and it's a sunny day in France. What else can you ask for?

BARTIROMO: This view is like the million dollar view behind me. You've got yachts lined up in the harbor here in Cannes. But we've been focused on marketing and on advertising here at Cannes Lions. They call this, Cheryl, the most creative week of the year for the media industry because you've got the creatives and the chief marketing officers coming to try to drum up business and give us a look at the year ahead in terms of what their advertising platforms look like.

CASONE: Yes. And how do they get to that younger consumer, that younger viewer, that younger reader, that customer --

BARTIROMO: That's right.

CASONE: -- that's what's so fascinating because obviously digital media has changed everything in our world.

BARTIROMO: Yes. You're absolutely right. And it doesn't matter what brand you are -- they're all facing that challenge.

And Lindsey -- this is another indicator of the economy, right because if businesses are sitting on cash, that means there's some uncertainty over there or if they're spending more ad dollars, that could be a positive indicator. How do you see the broad economy backdrop right now -- Lindsey?

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Right. I think you're getting some great indicators out of all of your interviews yesterday, today and the rest of this week. So (INAUDIBLE) CEO talking about how ad spend is up. We did see some cap ex numbers showing some signs of strength over the last couple of months.

The economy is doing really well and the consumer, it's being driven by a really resilient consumer here. Retail sales last week were really outstanding. The important thing there was that April numbers were also revised up and May numbers were solid.

So that is pushing GDP expectations for the second quarter above 2 percent, the Atlanta GDP now estimated is at 2.2 percent, up from 1.4 percent before that report.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and I know that the Atlanta fed changes pretty often in terms of its expectations. But the Fed is beginning the two-day meeting today. We're not expecting a cut in rates today but we'll see what happens down the road.

You've got to wonder what the 10 year is telling you, right. I mean you've got interest rates continuing at rock bottom levels.

CASONE: And you know, right now, we haven't seen a lot of action in the 10 year this week but it was certainly a market end indicator of volatility going back about a month ago. And I also think too, if you start to see more interest in the safety of bonds, that could be another sign that the Fed's going to have to look at.

I'm sure they're going to talk about all this today. You know, Lindsey brought this up to me on set during a commercial break. We're going to have that press conference tomorrow from Jay Powell. So that could be -- the Q&A part -- he's going to be asked about the President, he's going to be asked about the tariffs. I mean I can't wait to see how he responds.

BARTIROMO: Yes. What do you think the messaging out of the Fed, Lindsey, will be when Jay Powell takes the podium tomorrow?

BELL: I mean it's going to be tough for him. He's going to have to tap dance around a lot of difficult questions, I'm sure. But I think the message is going to be that the Fed is willing to stand by the markets in case the tariff situation escalates and it impacts the global economic environment. So I think the market will be reassured by that.

You also saw by the way the ECB came out today and Draghi is out there saying that he's willing to stand by and make changes should the economic environment weaken there.

BARTIROMO: Yes. They're all standing by, ready to act, should things turn lower. We'll see that.

So far, I'm really not seeing evidence that things are slowing down all that much with the exception of the purchasing manager's index, the PMI certainly. We'll keep watching that.

And joining the conversation this morning, we've got the head of Calibra at Facebook, David Marcus is joining us this morning. They are launching a new digital currency. So you want to hear that. Philip Morris International chief operating officer Jacek Olczak is also with us this morning to give us his sense of the global story. The global chief marketing officer at Lego Julia Goldin joining us. Along with former press secretary under President Trump and America First Action senior advisor Sean Spicer here. The host of "VARNEY & CO" weighs in as well, Stuart will join us later on in the show.

Don't miss a moment of it. We've a big two hours right now.

And President Trump just tweeted, here's what the President is saying this morning. "Mario Draghi just announced more stimulus could come which immediately dropped the euro against the dollar, making it unfairly easier for them to compete against the United States. They've been getting away with this for years, along with China and others," writes the President.

And of course this is a key point that the President makes, because oftentimes when there is stress, these countries, whether it is Mario Draghi in the E.U. or the President of China -- Lindsey, they'll devalue their currency.

BELL: Oh, yes. China has been -- they've been doing this for quite some time now. And you know, it's an offset to the tariffs that we have on Chinese goods coming into the U.S. It makes those goods cheaper for us. So it's a little bit of a relief for the consumer.

But it is an unfair practice. Currency should really purely be driven by free markets.

CASONE: And Maria -- we should add that European markets really rose this morning on these comments by Mario Draghi. I mean markets love stimulus and they love low interest rates and he's giving them what they want it seems.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And there's the rally you're seeing in the European indices. No doubt the President will address this at his kickoff to the road to 2020.

That's our top story right now. President Trump is kicking off his new campaign in Orlando, Florida today. Tens of thousands of people are expected to be at that rally, many waiting overnight for a chance to get into the rally to see the President. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KATE JENSEN, TRUMP SUPPORTER: I'm a Trump supporter. I think it's important to come and support him and show him that we are behind him 100 percent and approve of his agenda.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I love Trump. I do. I love what he does as far as military families. We have lost some loved ones. So I really appreciate how he has taken care of the family members, the service members, the wounded warriors, the gold star families -- all of them.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Hopefully he just sticks with the promises that he's made. He continues and just looking for another great four years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is former pollster for Trump presidential campaign, pollster at McLaughlin and Associates, president and partner Jim McLaughlin. Jim-- it's good to see you. Thanks so much for being here this morning.

JIM MCLAUGHLIN, POLLSTER, MCLAUGHLIN AND ASSOCIATES: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: What's your take on the President's chances for 2020 as he kicks off his new campaign today?

MCLAUGHLIN: Well, peace and prosperity usually wins elections and right now we've got a lot of prosperity. So I think his chances are really, really good right now.

And you know what's interesting? Last week, you know, forget about all the polls that are out there because I've got be honest with you, and I say this as a pollster. A lot of those polls right now they're totally irrelevant so far out from election day.

But the truth is, look at those three economic models including one that was done from an economist that worked for President Obama, they all said they thought not only was Donald Trump going to win, but he was going to win overwhelmingly. So that's very interesting out there and it's a great sign for President Trump.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But even though you're seeing all of these attacks on the President daily by the Democrats, they want to impeach him, they're completely ignoring any positive impact of his economic policies, for example.

MCLAUGHLIN: Yes. And that's why it's so important that the President is doing the announcement now.

It was perfect timing to be quite honest with you, because it's right before the first Democratic debates and it's going to set up the contrast.

Because the contrast is going to be Donald Trump, historic economy, wages are going up, jobs are going up, the most recent report where we talked about, it was you actually have -- there were more job openings out there for the 14th straight month than there are jobs to be filled.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

MCLAUGHLIN: So it's telling you right now how strong that economy is and that's the contrast he wants to take.

And you look at the Democrats, watch the Democrats at their debates, they're going to be calling for higher taxes. And the average American understands that. Middle class America knows that higher taxes are job killers. And that's the contrast that the President wants from now until Election Day.

BARTIROMO: You know, I don't get that. You've got to, you know, explain this to me. We know that the President's tax legislation and lower taxes actually put a spark in the economy. We saw 4.2 percent growth last year in one quarter.

MCLAUGHLIN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We're talking about 3.1 percent growth in the first quarter of this year. So how is it that the Democrats think that coming into office, raising taxes, is going to be a positive for the economy when we just saw the impact of the opposite?

MCLAUGHLIN: They have a big problem. They have an extreme radical liberal base that thinks this class warfare argument, going after the corporations, going afte3r the job creators, going after the 1 percent, they think helps them.

And while it may help them in a Democratic primary it hurts them with middle class America. Because people understand, when you talk about -- you know, the Democrats always say they're going to tax the rich. But the truth of the matter is, they get it that it's going to be small businesses and the middle class that are going to get the bulk of those tax increases and that's what's going to hurt the economy. And you know what, that's a great contrast for the President between now and election day.

BARTIROMO: Yes. You make a good point. But the Democrats are talking health care. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is vowing that Democrats will fight relentlessly to stop President Trump from repealing Obamacare. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA), SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: The President and some on the other side of the aisle have had scores of bills to eliminate the Affordable Care Act and we had to fight it every time to save it and then build it up bigger and grow it.

Right now, we are in court with the President of the United States. The Affordable Care Act is the law of the land. It's a place where the Justice Department is supposed to support the law of the land. Instead, the President has decided that instead of supporting the law of the land, he will overturn the law of the land.

It just doesn't make sense. It's not even -- it isn't even faithful to our belief as religious people. But nonetheless, we're in this fight.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Is that resonating -- Jim? I mean obviously healthcare is one of the top priorities for 2020. The President says that he's going to be rolling out a new healthcare plan in a couple months but we don't know what that will be. He says it is going to be a key focus of his re-election campaign, though.

MCLAUGHLIN: That clip that you just showed shows a real tension within the Democratic Party right now because most of the Democrats that are running for president right now, they're not supporting Obamacare. They're the ones that want to repeal and replace Obamacare with things like Medicare for all, which we all know is going to mean Medicare for none.

The interesting thing is the Republicans have done really well in the 2010 and the 2014 elections when they ran against Obamacare. And I think you're going to see the President do that again.

And what he's going to do is introduce some proposals that make healthcare more affordable, more accessible because that's what the American people are looking for.

BARTIROMO: You would think so. Jim -- it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

MCLAUGHLIN: Thank you. Always a pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Jim McLaughlin joining us there.

Coming up, more trouble this morning for Boeing as one of the top competitors, airbus, lays the ground work for its longest-range single aisle plane yet. We will tell you about it.

And then Crypto craze, Facebook officially announcing the highly anticipated details behind the launch of its digital currency.

We're going to get into it. I'll be speaking with Facebook's head of Calibra, David Marcus on what's in store for the future of Facebook and digital currency. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Now this. Another American dies in the Dominican Republic. Lauren Simonetti with the details on this mysterious story -- Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: The State Department Maria -- confirm that the body of a 55-year-old American tourist was found in the Dominican Republic. The New Jersey Man discovered last Thursday in his hotel, the cause of death has not been revealed. He's the ninth American to die in the country within the past year and-a-half.

Plus, dozens of tourists from Oklahoma say they got sick during a trip to the Caribbean nation back in April. They were part of a Jimmy Buffet fan group. Some of them testing positive for salmonella.

A scary moments for passengers on a flight to France. Severe turbulence injuring 10 passenger mid-air. 120 people were on-board this rocky ALK (ph) flight as drinks went flying through the air. A flight attendant's head smacked on the plane's ceiling at one point. The plane was heading from Kosovo. It did land safely in France, only minor injuries, believe it or not, reported as you watch that chaotic video.

Timing is everything especially when it comes to air travel. Forbes is ranking the fastest U.S. airlines in 2018. Finding Hawaiian Airlines had the best on-time record. Southwest number two. Followed by Allegiant Air, Delta and Spirit. But isn't Hawaiian Maria, always number one because the weather's good.

BARTIROMO: One of the reasons I have to say, yes.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Thanks -- Lauren.

Coming up, we're talking crypto -- Facebook crypto. It is coming. The networking giant formally releasing the highly anticipated details behind the digital exchange at Facebook. I'll talk with Facebook's head of Calibra, David Marcus is here an dhow the company is looking to disrupt the space.

And then targeting tobacco, Philip Morris International COO will join me in Cannes to talk about the FDA crackdown on e-cigarettes, nicotine and how it could hurt -- nicotine and how it could hurt the industry. We'll get a global outlook from him.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

President Trump just tweeting again. Here's what he just said. "European markets rose on comments unfair to the U.S. made today by Mario D." -- of course he's talking about Mario Draghi where we see the currency there going lower, given the fact that Mario Draghi has added stimulus to the European economy.

We're talking about stimulus this morning because the Federal Reserve kicked off a two-day meeting. And we will hear from Jay Powell tomorrow.

Meanwhile, tobacco industry has been growing for years. Philip Morris aiming to get out of the smokable tobacco and moving entirely to smokeless alternatives market. This as analysts at Morgan Stanley say an FDA proposal to limit nicotine could cost the industry $165 billion by 2035.

Joining me right now is the chief operating officer of Philip Morris International, Jacek Olczak. Jacek -- it's great to have you on the show this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

JACEK OLCZAK, CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER, PHILIP MORIS INTERNATIONAL: Thank you for having me.

BARTIROMO: So tell me about this, in terms of the FDA's move and what kind of an impact it's going to have for Philip Morris.

OLCZAK: Well, I think -- and the reason to, you know, get the smokers out of the combustible cigarette is that is a good reason. It's a good intervention as long as the consumer has alternatives. So our role is to supply the market with a scientifically verified alternative. In our case the heat not burned (INAUDIBLE) which we have to receive the PMPA (ph) authorization from FDA.

So I mean let it all (INAUDIBLE). I do believe that if all the forces align-- regulatory, consumer, communication, within 10 years we can fully get rid of smoking country by country.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

OLCZAK: We never had the opportunity in front of us so close and so materially in what we can do. I mean if I go to the countries where we started three and-a-half years ago, I mean the progress is tremendous.

I mean the smokers are looking for alternatives. Obviously the best way for them should be to quit smoking. The unfortunate thing is that people don't quit smoking. We provide them the products which today, you know, are vastly better than a conventional cigarettes.

BARTIROMO: Tell me the difference in terms of health, in terms of the impact on a person's body, cigarettes versus the vapes, like a Juul product, or e-cigarettes.

OLCZAK: I mean the difference is in the level of satisfaction delivered to the smoker, right. There is the (INAUDIBLE) component. There is the taste components. People smoke cigarette for the taste.

BARTIROMO: But is it a health risk? Is there a health risk on vapes and e-cigarettes as much as a health risk exists for cigarettes?

OLCZAK: No, they are not the same, none of the alternative products is risk-free. They do have a potential of being much lower risk to a consumer than continuing smoking. So I think at the end of the day, it's all in line with the (INAUDIBLE) reduction concept. You don't have a perfect product but this product is vastly better than this one.

And I think actually this whole confusion where many people will say that the e-cigarettes are (INAUDIBLE) product -- they're not risk-free. You're passing the wrong message to consumers because it allows them to stay, forces them to stay in a conventional product which is bd for them.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, this is why I'm asking you. People need to understand the difference. I don't think people have really explained that very well.

And then you've got this whole story about regulation. Are you expecting even further regulation of the industry? San Francisco officials for example voting today on whether to ban e-cigarette sales.

OLCZAK: I don't think it's the right thing to do, frankly speaking.

BARTIROMO: It still needs another yes vote before the law but the legislation has been -- it could make San Francisco the first city to ban e-cigarettes.

OLCZAK: Ok. I think there was a lot of emotional elements in the discussions. I mean they should go back to the facts. I mean e-cigarettes are a better product than the conventional cigarette. So I don't fully understand why on the one hand we're banning the better product while the sales of the other product is allowed. That doesn't really make sense.

It's about the solving the problem of smoking. And for a company like Philip Morris International to make the statement, they're willing to go smoke-free, that they are willing to solve the problem of smoking. And I put all my resources, marketing, production, R&D, et cetera to go beyond this whole thing. I would expect that, you know, other people who are truly interested in solving the problem of smoking will go with me.

And I hear from time to time that there are some interventions which don't really, you know, solve the problem. That's where the people -- you have 40 million smoking Americans. I think they do deserve better treatment.

BARTIROMO: You're right. That's a good point. How have you changed your business as a result of all of this pushback on nicotine?

OLCZAK: We have decided that this is not additional product to our portfolio. If this product is better than cigarettes, let's get rid of cigarettes and we're preferring -- every year we're making progress. Today we sell $40 billion of our products in 48 markets. We are ready to go to the next market, working for the solutions for the market in general degree (ph) because we have to remember smoking is not just the habit if you like of the rich people. It's also you have people with lower income. We need a solution for those people.

BARTIROMO: Of course. Real quick, before we go. Where is the growth at Philip Morris coming from in the next five years.

OLCZAK: From a new product. Entirely from a new product. We essentially stopped investing behind old products.

I mean this year alone, I mean we've now given a full year we already shut down the three factories manufacturing combustible cigarettes. We just truly want to get rid of smoking.

BARTIROMO: That's fascinating that you could shift your business in such a significant way.

Jacek -- thanks very much for joining us to talk about it.

OLCZAK: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. Jacek Olczak joining us there from Philip Morris International.

Coming up, Facebook crypto is coming. The networking giant releasing the highly anticipated details behind the digital exchange. I'll be speaking with Facebook's head of Calibra, David Marcus, on how the company is looking to disrupt the space. That's coming up next.

And then I'm talking this morning with the CMO of the iconic children's toy company Lego on the brand's expansion into theme parks.

Back in a minute with all of that.

ANNOUNCER: Here again is Maria Bartiromo, with a special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA, live from France at the 2019 Cannes Lions.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us as we come to you live from Cannes this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, June 18th. Your top stories right now, 7:32 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets are higher, Futures pointing toward a higher opening as the two-day Federal Reserve meeting kicks off today and U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer testifies before the Senate on China trade and USMCA later this morning.

Dow Industrials right now up 113 points, one half of one percent, S&P Futures up 13-3/4 and the NASDAQ Futures higher by 62-1/2, almost one percent.

On top of gains yesterday, even though they were fractional, yesterday markets were up at the close, Dow Industrials up 22, the S&P less than two percent away from its record high with a gain of just two points and the NASDAQ was up 48 points at the close yesterday.

The momentum continues this morning here in Europe, European markets are up after the European Central Bank President Mario Draghi signaled more stimulus for the Eurozone is on the way. The European markets are up, FT- 100 up 60 points, CAC Quarante in Paris up 75, and the DAX Index in Germany up 143 points, better than one percent.

In Asia overnight markets are mostly higher, take a look, with the exception of Japan. The NIKKEI was down three-quarters of a percent but the Hang Seng in Hong Kong was up one percent.

U.S. Treasury yields are lower this morning, falling, the 10 year yield hitting a 21-month low as the Fed kicks off its two-day meeting. That yield now at 2.03 percent. Falling for a sixth straight session.

Apple T.V. getting an upgrade. Find out the latest features being added to enhance the viewing experience.

And a real life Iron Man, check this out, look at the bulletproof suit that has been built and it can actually fly. Yes, find out who made it. We've got all the details coming up.

First though, President Trump is just tweeting this morning and here's what he just said. The fake news doesn't report it but Republican enthusiasm is at an all-time high. Look what is going on in Orlando, Florida right now. People have never seen anything like it unless you play a guitar, going to be wild. See you later. The president of course is kicking off his 2020 campaign today in Orlando. He's gearing up for a big crowds this afternoon.

All that coming up this morning. But first, our top story this half an hour, Facebook's cryptocurrency. The social media giant is sharing plans for Calibra, that's a newly formed subsidiary of Facebook that will allow people to actually participate in the new Libra digital currency. The Libra Network expected to launch a digital currency next year called Libra. Dozens of companies like eBay, Spotify, PayPal and Uber have already signed on as partners for this. And we're going to talk more about this coming up.

You know, when you look at Bitcoin and the success of Bitcoin, Cheryl Casone, you've got to believe that there's a market for this and when you look at what has taken place in terms of the competitors to Bitcoin, you've got to say that another digital currency further legitimizes this market.

CASONE: Certainly you're going to get more competition likely. It may not be this year, it may not be next year but it could be maybe 10, 15 years out. Well, digital cryptocurrency has got issues. It's got safety issues. There was a huge theft in one of the Bitcoin exchanges over in Asia just about a month ago. So they've got to be able to -- and I think Facebook is going to have to face this, they're going to have to make sure that they've got everything safely in place so that you don't get that kind of theft and I'm sure they do. They do have this big partnerships that you talked about.

But again, is it going to be Bitcoin, another cryptocurrency, who knows? But whether you're Goldman Sachs or you're J.P. Morgan, all of the big banks here in New York, on Wall Street, they're looking at this market and even Lloyd Blankfein said, initially he was kind of a doubter as was Jamie Dimon. They're now saying, OK, Bitcoin is the kind of market they want to be a part in. And I think that does legitimize the cryptocurrency.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's really funny. I love the Jamie Dimon story. Because Jamie Dimon initially came out saying no way, we're never going to trade Bitcoin, it's not what we do, we don't -- we're not believers, until his daughter made so much money on it. She bought it and then she looked like a genius and he said, well, wait a minute, let me look at that again.

You know, this is the first time that we're getting the list of companies that are actually participating, Lindsey. So when you see companies like eBay, Spotify, PayPal, you know, Uber, they've signed onto this partnership and there are others, big companies. That's got to give it legs as well.

BELL: Yes, I think it definitely gives it legs. It legitimizes it as Cheryl said. I think this is really just when you think about cryptocurrency, this is just the next evolution of it. We're still in very early stages within this asset class. So it's very good to see these companies piling on, joining forces with Facebook.

Again, like I said earlier, this is going to be a cryptocurrency that's actually backed by government securities. Hopefully making it more stable and reliable option if you're looking to get into the crypto space.

BARTIROMO: But it was really the block chain technology that most people said that they believe in that. Now, Facebook built its own block chain, Cheryl, and it's based on that. But for a long time, people were thinking, I'm not sure about digital currencies but I'm definitely a believer in block chain.

CASONE: Right, block chain really became the story out of the Bitcoin story to your point. But also, you know, you have to look at these companies and ask yourself, especially these large companies like your eBay, your Spotify, your PayPal, if they would be willing to go into this market. If it wasn't more solid and more safe and I think that that -- this news we got today out of Facebook is telling us that it is.

You did have a guest in the last hour though, on the show talking about the issue of regulation. You've already got the government going after big technology. Not just the U.S. government, but the Europeans, (AUDIO GAP) more regulation on this market. You know, coming in the future as well as (INAUDIBLE) all these calls to break up big tech and Alphabet and everybody else. I mean, it's a little bit of a -- of a question mark right now.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and you know, they've been building out this cryptocurrency for over a year. I believe it was the Wall Street Journal which first reported that they were building this out and now today we're getting the confirmation. David Marcus is going to join us shortly to talk more about that. So we'll get back to that when David Marcus joins us.

Meanwhile, in terms of the broad story, lifting markets this morning, it's got to be about the Fed, ladies, right? I mean, the Federal Reserve is probably not going to -- you know, cut rates today, although there is a portion of Wall Street and investors who think they will. But what's behind this rally here is the fact that it looks like whether it's today or in the next couple of months, the next move from the Fed is probably a cut.

BELL: Yes, I think the ECB's commentary this morning about their willingness to deploy stimulus if necessary really puts pressure on Jay Powell over the course of their meetings today and tomorrow and especially in the -- in the press conference tomorrow.

So of course, we're expecting the Fed to signal their willingness to be a little more accommodative if their -- the situation arises where economic data starts getting much weaker than what we have seen. But we don't expect a move at this meeting.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll take a short break. You've got to wonder what a 2.03 percent 10 year yield tells us about the broad economy and whether or not we're going to see a slowdown. We're going to talk with Facebook's David Marcus on cryptocurrency when we come back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. And as promised, joining us right now is the Facebook head of Calibra, he is our special guest from Menlo Park, California, David Marcus. And David, it's great to have you on the program this morning. Thanks so much for being here.

DAVID MARCUS, HEAD OF CALIBRA, FACEBOOK: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: So the Wall Street Journal has been reporting that you've been working on this digital currency for over a year. Can you tell us about Libra and what you're unveiling this morning?

MARCUS: Well, we are unveiling our plans for a new type of block chain, one that can actually scale to meets the demands of billions of people that we ultimately want to serve when it launches at some point next year. A new cryptocurrency which unlike other cryptocurrencies is not, you know, volatile. So it's not -- it's not an investment asset. It's designed from the ground-up to be a medium of exchange, a great form of digitally native currency.

And all of that is actually going to be governed by a non for profit association that is going to be managed by its members and we're starting with 27 other companies, this journey. And hopefully by the time this network goes live, over a hundred different global organizations that will help manage and govern this new network and this new currency.

And then on the other side of that, which you know, the association is something that will just be one of many governing. We will have a digital wallet called Calibra that will both be a standalone app but also be embedded in WhatsApp and Messenger so that anyone can on-ramp and off-ramp to this new digital currency and pay one another across the world.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, it's interesting, this network of companies that you've already got on-board. Can you explain to us why Libra is better or might be better than what's on the market already, like for example, Bitcoin?

MARCUS: Well, I think two differences. And so, first of all, the companies, the reason that we couldn't go alone here is because if you want to build an internet of money or a protocol for value on the existing internet, this is not something that should be controlled by one company. It should be controlled and governed, you know, as a public good, the same way the internet is. So eventually, we'll get there.

But to start, we had to ensure that this was governed by a number of institutions and global organizations and not by Facebook.

And then we go to your question on how different it is than Bitcoin, I think, you know, the first thing is Bitcoin today, I see it as an investment assets that's decorrelated from all kind of different investment assets, but it's not a great medium of exchange today because you know, good currency is actually very stable. And Bitcoin is volatile which is -- you know, its feature if you're looking at it from an investment standpoint.

The other difference is the network on top -- on top of which Libra will run and this block chain is designed from the ground-up to be able to process thousands of transactions per second, eventually, so meeting the demands for potentially billions of people that will end up hopefully one day using this new network and asset.

BARTIROMO: So David, answer the critics because obviously Facebook has faced plenty of criticism over privacy concerns, privacy breaches, that's the business model, selling people's data to advertising. So is that going to be addressed now that money is involved? How do you -- how do you square the circle on this and get people's trust, given the fact that there's been a breach of trust in the last couple of years?

MARCUS: Well, I mean, that's a really good question. And obviously something we've thought about for a very long time. So first and foremost, to use Libra, you will not need to use a Facebook product if you don't want to. There will be plenty of wallets offering similar services than, you know, Calibra will offer. So you can choose whatever wallet you want. And by the way, all the wallets will be interoperable with one another because they'll run on top of the same network.

So, you know, if we want people to trust us with this new service, we'll have to basically deserve their trust and the way that we are doing this is that, you know, we've created this separate entity that is going to be a regulated entity, Calibra, and we heard people loud and clear. They don't want their financial data co-mingled with their social data and they certainly don't want their financial data being used for ad targeting and all these things and so that's what we're doing.

Basically Facebook Inc. will not have access to financial data that you'll have inside of Calibra. So we're clearly separating things and we've create a lot of competition on this network that we've helped start.

BARTIROMO: Yes, real quick, is this an effort by Facebook to diversify the business, given the issues on the -- on the privacy breach side?

MARCUS: Sorry, I couldn't hear at the beginning of your question.

BARTIROMO: Is this your effort to diversify the business, given the fact that you faced criticism over the privacy breaches?

MARCUS: No. I don't think this --

BARTIROMO: You know, you look at some of your early investors, like Roger McNamee, right. He was such a fan and remains a huge investor. But he'll say he's been on this program and said, look, this is the company's business model and there's nowhere to go. I mean, this is what they do. So is this your effort to diversify the revenue stream to broaden out so you're not married to that revenue stream only, selling people's data to advertisers?

MARCUS: Well, first of all, let me just defend our business model for a second because I think it's a great business model, actually, and I don't think that the business model is the issue here. First of all, we're not selling data to advertisers and the ability for us to actually run ads on the platform is the way we offer the service for free to billions of people around the world. This is the way that 90 million small businesses are actually growing their businesses because they have an ability to reach new customers and it powers the economy of small businesses around the world.

So the business model at Facebook is not the issue. I think that there are number of things that we should have done better over the past few years but you've seen that we've invested and we're continuing to invest a great deal to improve with those things. And now with this new network, we're even going a step further which is basically relinquishing a lot of our governance and a lot of our influence over this network that we've helped create to create a level playing field and basically you know, compete with others.

BARTIROMO: Yes, well, it certainly is a hot spot. David, great to see you. Thanks so much.

MARCUS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: David Marcus joining us at Facebook.

Coming up, we're looking at Lego. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Lego, one of the most beloved toy brands ever for decades, kids and adults enjoying those iconic plastic building blocks. And increasing market shares of video games become more and more popular.

Joining me right now is the chief marketing officer of Lego Global, Julia Goldin. Julia, it's great to have you on the show this morning.

JULIA GOLDIN, CHIEF MARKETING OFFICER, LEGO GLOBAL: Thank you. Excited to be here.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. What has been the impact of Lego -- to Lego, rather, when you see things like gaming and other entertainment really rising in popularity as well? Have you seen an impact?

GOLDIN: Well, kids change all the time. And of course the world has changed a lot and what we see is that kids very much enjoy what they called fluid play. Because we do a lot of insights and investigations with kids, we observe them, we talk to them. And what they like is switching between the different worlds. So that has created a lot of opportunity for them to engage with them in different ways.

Kids have always loved digital games from Lego. That has already been in existence for a long time. But what we're doing now is also connecting the physical experience with the digital experience. For example, you know, we have a new theme that's coming out this year, just in the couple of months called Hidden Side. And that's where kids are going to be able to build physically and then enjoy n augmented reality experience around their game -- around the set that they build which brings the world to life. So it has created a lot of opportunity for us to tap into new ways in which kids play and also new ways of engaging with them.

BARTIROMO: And you've got to sell this in terms of marketing. Tell us how your marketing has changed to engage new audiences.

GOLDIN: Well, marketing has definitely gone through a big revolution and evolution over the last few years because of the invention of digital and formation of digital platforms. But when it comes to engaging with kids, we tend to be super audience focused. Meaning that we really try to understand what they're into, what passions they have. But we also want to make sure that we engage with them in a very safe way in terms of digital.

So marketing model has definitely evolved. Whereas before it was much more focused on traditional media. Now, of course we engage a lot more in the digital space. But we also have other ways of engaging, for example, we've launched our own digital platform called Lego Life, it's a completely safe digital platform for kids and they really love it.

We also have Lego YouTube, we have Lego T.V. So there's a lot of different up ways in which we are now delivering content to them and engaging them on their favorite themes.

BARTIROMO: That is so fantastic. I love your business card. It is a little Lego with your name and number on the back. It's just so fascinating. You're still seeing growth continuing to grow at Lego?

GOLDIN: Absolutely. Well, we have a very strong purpose which is to inspire and develop the builders of tomorrow. So for us, every child is that opportunity.

BARTIROMO: Julia, thank you so much. Congratulations. Julia Goldin from Lego. We'll be right back.

GOLDIN: Thank you.
