urn:contentItem:5WDK-TJV1-JCJY-G3YB-00000-00Facebook says breaking itself up will not solve issues of privacy or election interference and warns there is a 'battle' for tech dominance between the US and China2019-06-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:39ZLexisNexisNEWSVersion:5Facebook says breaking itself up will not solve issues of privacy or election interference and warns there is a 'battle' for tech dominance between the US and ChinaJennifer SmithDavid Wilcock, Whitehall Correspondent For Mailonline

Nick Clegg, the company's head of global affairs, made the comments on Monday

The British former politician said the company was not resisting government regulation but that it does not think it should break itself up

It has been urged by investors to split Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp

Critics say the company has too much power over global social media

Facebook has proposed a different solution - an independent Oversight Board of 40 people who will decide what is and what is not appropriate

The idea has been shot down by critics who say it needs outside regulation

Facebook has insisted breaking itself up into branches, as it has been urged to do, will not resolve issues of privacy or election interference and says a more pressing problem is the battle for tech dominance between the US and China.

In an interview with the BBC on Monday, the company's head of global affairs, British former Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg, said it was not trying to shun government regulation but said that the kind being proposed by the likes of Elizabeth Warren would not address its problems.

Warren, a Massachusetts Senator and presidential hopeful, has called for Facebook to sell or relinquish control of its subsidiaries Instagram and WhatsApp, claiming its current infrastructure gives it too much power.

Zuckerberg is fighting back against her demands.

Separately, the company has been accused of not doing enough to protect user data or act as a referee deciding what should and should not be allowed on its platform.

On that issue, with particular regard to advertising and political speech, Zuckerberg says it should not be up to him to decide an industry standard.

On Monday, Clegg said that while he hadn't drank the 'Kool Aid of Silicon Valley', he also disagreed with a proposed break-up of the company.

'I haven't drunk the Kool Aid completely in Silicon Valley, I do try and remain objective. I would, in a sense, put the burden of proof on those who are advocating the break-up of these tech companies; does it achieve what people want it to achieve?

'Does it really resolve the issues around privacy or interference - alleged interference - in elections, or how we adjudicate on hate speech?

'None of those problems go away by dismembering a company,' he said.

Echoing comments made by Zuckerberg earlier in the year about how it should not be up to Facebook to pave the way for others on what should and should not be acceptable in technology, he added: 'I don't think it's in any way conceivable, and I don't think it's right, for private companies to set the rules of the road for something which is as profoundly important as how technology serves society.

'In the end this is not something that big tech companies... can or should do on their own.

'I want to see... companies like Facebook play an increasingly mature role - not shunning regulation but advocating it in a sensible way,' he said.

He went on to say there had been a 'techlash' against media firms that would help China gain dominance.

'I think the pendulum has swung really quite rapidly from the tech utopia, the tech euphoria of a few years ago when people like Mark Zuckerberg could do no wrong.

'It's now swung the other way to a sort of tech phobia where people like Mark Zuckerberg can do no right.

'The danger is if that techlash topples from skepticism about tech into outright phobia of it, I think we end up with the risk that we throw the baby out with the bathwater and we make it almost impossible for tech to innovate properly,' he said.

He added that there was a 'battle for dominance' between the US and China - something that has been playing out politically for months if not years.

'Crucially, let's remember you have this battle for tech dominance between the United States and China.

'In China there is no compunction about how data is used, there is no worry about privacy legislation, data protection and so on.

'We should not emulate what China is doing, (but) we should keep our ability in Europe and North America to innovate and use data proportionately and innovatively.

'Otherwise if we deprive ourselves of that ability I can predict that in a relatively short period of time we will have tech domination from a country with wholly different sets of values to those that are shared in this country (UK) and elsewhere,' he said.

Facebook's proposed solution to its problems is a 40-person Oversight Board, which will rule on what is and isn't appropriate content.

This has been likened to a 'Supreme Court' for one of the internet's largest communities, in which the panel will adjudicate over what content should be available to more than 2.6billion Facebook users across the globe.

The company has vowed to make the panel independent, but critics remain convinced the platform needs government or external regulation and that it cannot be left to discipline itself.

Clegg will also give a speech in Berlin on Monday detailing its plan for the Oversight Board.

In April, investors urged Zuckerberg to split up the company and called his leadership a 'dictatorship' in SEC filings.

'Facebook operates essentially as a dictatorship. Mark Zuckerberg controls a majority of the votes using a multi-class share structure with unequal voting rights... 'Fake news, election interference, threats to our bottom line and our democracy.

'Shareholders need more than deny, deflect, and delay.

'We need a real voice through governance reforms, including Majority Vote requirements to elect directors,' one shareholder group said.

Since then, they have demanded that Zuckerberg give up some of his individual positions too.

The US's trade war with China extended to tech earlier this year when Trump vowed to stop all US companies doing business with Huawei, one of the world's largest smartphone providers.

His concerns were based on the company's connections to individuals with ties to the Chinese government.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60FP-SDP1-DY93-M0NY-00000-00Facebook says EU antitrust probe invades employee privacy2020-07-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:38ZLexisNexisFacebook says EU antitrust probe invades employee privacySan Francisco, July 28 2020

Facebook on Monday said it is asking EU courts to review "exceptionally broad" requests by antitrust regulators there that would scoop up employees' personal information.

The US-based internet colossus maintained it has been cooperating with a European Commission antitrust investigation and will continue to do so, but that the wording of commission requests casts a net so wide it will haul in Facebook employees' private messages and more.

The leading social network expects to give the commission hundreds of thousands of documents, according to Facebook associate general counsel for competition Tim Lamb

"The exceptionally broad nature of the commission's requests means we would be required to turn over predominantly irrelevant documents that have nothing to do with the commission's investigations," Lamb said in response to an AFP inquiry.

Those documents include "highly sensitive personal information such as employees' medical information; personal financial documents, and private information about family members of employees."

Facebook thinks such requests should be reviewed by EU courts, according to Lamb, and is asking the court to weigh in on broad search terms such as "applause" or "for free" that could easily be found in personal email messages or other exchanges way beyond the scope of antitrust matters.

Regulatory probes can involve requests for messages or documents bearing certain words or phrases, with those seeking information inclined to craft wide nets and those being queried wanting them narrowly targeted.

A highly anticipated US antitrust hearing, including top executives of four Big Tech firms, originally set for Monday was postponed to Wednesday.

The House Judiciary Committee hearing titled "Examining the Dominance of Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google" will feature the chief executives of all four companies: Tim Cook of Apple, Jeff Bezos of Amazon, Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook and Sundar Pichai of Google and its parent firm Alphabet.

The hearing comes amid rising concerns over Big Tech dominance, which has become even more pronounced during the coronavirus pandemic and coincides with investigations at the federal and state levels into the online giants.

The session was postponed due to the memorial service for the late representative and civil rights leader John Lewis, who will lie in state in the US Capitol until Tuesday.

APPLE INC.

GOOGLE

A highly anticipated US antitrust hearing , including top executives of four Big Tech firms, originally set for Monday was postponed to Wednesday. The House Judiciary Committee hearing titled "Examining the Dominance of Amazon, Apple , Facebook , and Google " will feature the chief executives of all four companies: Tim Cook of Apple , Jeff Bezos of Amazon, Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook and Sundar Pichai of Google and its parent firm Alphabet. The hearing comes amid rising concerns over Big Tech dominance, which has become even more pronounced during the coronavirus pandemic and coincides with investigations at the Federal and state levels into the online giants. The session was postponed due to the memorial service for the late representative and civil rights leader John Lewis, who will lie in state in the US Capitol until Tuesday.

Facebook on Monday said it is asking EU courts to review "exceptionally broad" requests by antitrust regulators there that would scoop up employees' personal information. The US-based internet colossus maintained it has been cooperating with a European Com...

Facebook on Monday said it is asking EU courts to review "exceptionally broad" requests by antitrust regulators there that would scoop up employees' personal information. The US-based internet colossus maintained it has been cooperating with a European Commission antitrust investigation and will continue to do so, but that the wording of commission requests casts a net so wide it will haul in Facebook employees' private messages and more. The leading social network expects to give the commission hundreds of thousands of documents, according to Facebook associate general counsel for competition Tim Lamb. "The exceptionally broad nature of the commission's requests means we would be required to turn over predominantly irrelevant documents that have nothing to do with the commission's investigations," Lamb said in response to an AFP inquiry. Those documents include "highly sensitive personal information such as employees' medical information; personal financial documents, and private information about family members of employees." Facebook thinks such requests should be reviewed by EU courts, according to Lamb, and is asking the court to weigh in on broad search terms such as "applause" or "for free" that could easily be found in personal email messages or other exchanges way beyond the scope of antitrust matters. Regulatory probes can involve requests for messages or documents bearing certain words or phrases, with those seeking information inclined to craft wide nets and those being queried wanting them narrowly targeted. A highly anticipated US antitrust hearing, including top executives of four Big Tech firms, was originally set for Monday but has been postponed. A notice filed by the House Judiciary Committee set no new date for the hearing titled "Examining the Dominance of Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google." The hearing would have conflicted with the memorial service for the late representative and civil rights leader John Lewis, who will lie in state in the US Capitol until Tuesday. The antitrust hearing was called amid rising concerns over Big Tech dominance, which has become even more pronounced during the coronavirus pandemic and coincides with investigations at the federal and state levels into the online giants. SAN FRANCISCO - Facebook on Monday said it is asking EU courts to review "exceptionally broad" requests by antitrust regulators there that would scoop up employees' personal information. The US-based internet colossus maintained it has been cooperating with a European Commission antitrust investigation and will continue to do so, but that the wording of commission requests casts a net so wide it will haul in Facebook employees' private messages and more. The leading social network expects to give the commission hundreds of thousands of documents, according to Facebook associate general counsel for competition Tim Lamb "The exceptionally broad nature of the commission's requests means we would be required to turn over predominantly irrelevant documents that have nothing to do with the commission's investigations," Lamb said in response to an AFP inquiry. Those documents include "highly sensitive personal information such as employees' medical information; personal financial documents, and private information about family members of employees." Facebook thinks such requests should be reviewed by EU courts, according to Lamb, and is asking the court to weigh in on broad search terms such as "applause" or "for free" that could easily be found in personal email messages or other exchanges way beyond the scope of antitrust matters. Regulatory probes can involve requests for messages or documents bearing certain words or phrases, with those seeking information inclined to craft wide nets and those being queried wanting them narrowly targeted. A highly anticipated US antitrust hearing, including top executives of four Big Tech firms, was originally set for Monday but has been postponed. A notice filed by the House Judiciary Committee set no new date for the hearing titled "Examining the Dominance of Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google." The hearing would have conflicted with the memorial service for the late representative and civil rights leader John Lewis, who will lie in state in the US Capitol until Tuesday. The antitrust hearing was called amid rising concerns over Big Tech dominance, which has become even more pronounced during the coronavirus pandemic and coincides with investigations at the federal and state levels into the online giants. Chief executives Tim Cook of Apple, Jeff Bezos of Amazon, Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook and Sundar Pichai of Google and its parent firm Alphabet had agreed to participate in the session. © Agence France-Presse

value.Title: Facebook says EU antitrust probe invades employee privacy

urn:contentItem:60G1-1951-F07F-82R8-00000-00Facebook says EU antitrust probe invades employee privacy2020-07-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:39ZLexisNexisNEWSFacebook says EU antitrust probe invades employee privacy

The US-based internet colossus maintained it has been cooperating with a European Commission antitrust investigation and will continue to do so, but that the wording of commission requests casts a net so wide it will haul in Facebook employees’ private mes... The US-based internet colossus maintained...

The US-based internet colossus maintained it has been cooperating with a European Commission antitrust investigation and will continue to do so, but that the wording of commission requests casts a net so wide it will haul in Facebook employees’ private mes...

The US-based internet colossus maintained it has been cooperating with a European Commission antitrust investigation and will continue to do so, but that the wording of commission requests casts a net so wide it will haul in Facebook employees’ private messages and more. — AFP pic SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 — Facebook yesterday said it is asking EU courts to review “exceptionally broad” requests by antitrust regulators there that would scoop up employees’ personal information. The US-based internet colossus maintained it has been cooperating with a European Commission antitrust investigation and will continue to do so, but that the wording of commission requests casts a net so wide it will haul in Facebook employees’ private messages and more. The leading social network expects to give the commission hundreds of thousands of documents, according to Facebook associate general counsel for competition Tim Lamb. “The exceptionally broad nature of the commission’s requests means we would be required to turn over predominantly irrelevant documents that have nothing to do with the commission’s investigations,” Lamb said in response to an AFP inquiry. Those documents include “highly sensitive personal information such as employees’ medical information; personal financial documents, and private information about family members of employees.” Facebook thinks such requests should be reviewed by EU courts, according to Lamb, and is asking the court to weigh in on broad search terms such as “applause” or “for free” that could easily be found in personal email messages or other exchanges way beyond the scope of antitrust matters. Regulatory probes can involve requests for messages or documents bearing certain words or phrases, with those seeking information inclined to craft wide nets and those being queried wanting them narrowly targeted. A highly anticipated US antitrust hearing, including top executives of four Big Tech firms, originally set for yesterday was postponed to tomorrow. The House Judiciary Committee hearing titled “Examining the Dominance of Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google” will feature the chief executives of all four companies: Tim Cook of Apple, Jeff Bezos of Amazon, Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook and Sundar Pichai of Google and its parent firm Alphabet. The hearing comes amid rising concerns over Big Tech dominance, which has become even more pronounced during the coronavirus pandemic and coincides with investigations at the federal and state levels into the online giants. The session was postponed due to the memorial service for the late representative and civil rights leader John Lewis, who will lie in state in the US Capitol until today. — AFP
